revision.comment: Journey to the Center of the Earth
revision.text:
{{Infobox television | show_name = Journey to the Center of the Earth | image = File:Journey to the Center of the Earth (1993) Film Poster.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = Film Poster | genre = Sci-fi | creator = | based_on = {{based on|''[[Journey to the Center of the Earth]]''
1864 novel|[[Jules Verne]]}} | writer = | screenplay = [[David M. Evans]]
Robert Gunter | story = | director = [[William Dear]] | starring = David Dundara
[[Farrah Forke]]
[[Tim Russ]]
[[Jeffrey Nordling]]
[[John Neville (actor)|John Neville]] | narrated = David Dundara | theme_music_composer = [[David Kurtz (composer)|David Kurtz]]
[[Christopher Franke]] | country = Canada
United States | language = English | num_episodes = 1 | producer = [[John Ashley (actor)|John Ashley]] | editor = Barry L. Gold | cinematography = [[Ronald Víctor García]] | runtime = 90 min. | company = [[Columbia Pictures Television]] | distributor = [[National Broadcasting Company]] | budget = | network = [[NBC]] | first_aired = 28 February 1993 | last_aired = | website = }} The 1993 '''Journey to the Center of the Earth''' is a TV film first aired on NBC. It stars [[Carel Struycken]], [[Tim Russ]], and [[Jeffrey Nordling]], John Neville, [[F. Murray Abraham]], [[Fabiana Udenio]], and [[Kim Miyori]]. A TV series was originally planned after its release but it was cancelled. == Plot == A team of explorers sets on a voyage to the earth's core, following an earlier attempt years before. Their ship, ''Avenger'', enters the lava chamber of an active volcano and uses an energy ray called a "sonic blaster" to blast through the flow. They enter in a subterranean world over 100 kilometers below the Earth's surface. The place is filled with many strange creatures. As they explore deeper into the underground caverns they encounter a [[yeti]] which the crew named Dallas that serves as their guide. Meanwhile, an unknown malevolent entity is attempting to recover the missing pieces of an [[Atlantis|Atlantean]] artifact known as the "book of knowledge" one of which a crew member of the Avenger brought with him, that will supposedly give massive powers to whomever possesses it. ==Cast== * David Dundara as Anthony LaStrella * [[Farrah Forke]] as Dr. Margo Peterson * [[Kim Miyori]] as Dr. Tesue Ishikawa * [[John Neville (actor)|John Neville]] as Dr. Cecil Chambers * [[Jeffrey Nordling]] as Chris Turner * [[Tim Russ]] as Joe Briggs * [[Carel Struycken]] as Dallas * [[Fabiana Udenio]] as Sandra Miller * [[Justina Vail]] as Devin * [[F. Murray Abraham]] as Professor Harlech * [[Francis Guinan]] as Mr. Wentworth * Cassie Byram as Secretary * Connie Craig as Student #1 * Doug Freimuth as Student #2 * Ben Cleaveland as Student #3 ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0107279|Journey to the Center of the Earth}} * {{amg movie|135403}} * {{tcmdb title|id=468695}} * [http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/10004766-journey_to_the_center_of_the_earth/ ''Journey to the Center of the Earth''] at Rotten Tomatoes {{Journey to the Center of the Earth}} [[Category:1993 television films]] [[Category:NBC network original films]] [[Category:Travel to the Earth's center]] [[Category:Films based on Journey to the Center of the Earth]] [[Category:American science fiction television films]] [[Category:1990s science fiction films]]

{{Lowercase}}
The abbreviation '''kyr''' means "thousand years".
Kyr was formerly common in some [[English language]] works, especially in [[geology]] and [[astronomy]], for the [[physical unit|unit]] of 1,000 years or [[millennium]]. The "k" is the [[SI prefix|unit prefix]] for [[kilo-]] or thousand with the suffix "yr" simply an abbreviation for "year".
Occasionally, the "k" is shown in [[upper case]], as in "100 Kyr"; this is an incorrect usage. "kyr" itself is often considered incorrect, with some preferring to use "ky".
[[ISO 80000-3]] recommends usage of ka (for [[kiloannum]]), which avoids the implicit English bias of "year" by using a [[Latin]] root.
==See also== * [[Annum]] * [[Myr]] * [[Byr]]
==External links== *[http://www.unc.edu/~rowlett/units/dictA.html How Many? A Dictionary of Units of Measurement, A] *[http://www.unc.edu/~rowlett/units/dictK.html How Many? A Dictionary of Units of Measurement, K] *[http://www.unc.edu/~rowlett/units/dictY.html How Many? A Dictionary of Units of Measurement, Y]
[[Category:Units of time]] [[Category:Geology]] [[Category:Astronomy]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 1 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v1.6.1)
revision.text:
'''Larry Persily''' was Federal Coordinator (director) of the [[Alaska Natural Gas Transportation Projects]] 2010-2015. The Federal Coordinator is [[advice and consent|nominated with advice and consent of the Senate]] by the [[President of the United States]].<ref name="USA Alaska">"Across the USA: Alaska:Fairbanks," ''USA Today'', November 13, 2009, p. 13A.</ref><ref name="Drue Pearce">[http://www.arcticgas.gov/bio/pearce-drue Alaska Natural Gas Transportation Projects government website biography of Drue Pearce] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100808140901/http://www.arcticgas.gov/bio/pearce-drue |date=2010-08-08 }}. Accessed August 6, 2010</ref> He was nominated by [[Barack Obama]] on December 9, 2009, and was confirmed by the United States Senate on March 10, 2010.<ref name="Larry Persily">[http://www.arcticgas.gov/bio/persily-larry Alaska Natural Gas Transportation Projects government website biography of Larry Persily]. Accessed August 6, 2010</ref><ref name=Forgey>Pat Forgey, "Persily wins confirmation in US Senate: Begich says Obama will elevate position into executive office", ''Juneau Empire'', March 11, 2010. Found at [http://juneauempire.com/stories/031110/loc_583250278.shtml Jurneau Empire website]. Accessed September 12, 2010.</ref>
Persily criticized his former employer, then-Governor [[Sarah Palin]], as [[John McCain]]'s choice for vice president.<ref name=Palin>Tony Hopfinger and Ken Fireman, "McCain Defends Sarah Palin as Some Alaskans Question His Choice," August 31, 2008. Found at [https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=a1uiw5Tqp4EM Bloomberg News]. Accessed August 10, 2010</ref> Until June 2008, he had worked as the [[Washington, DC]] liaison for the state government of [[Alaska]].<ref name=Palin /> "She's not qualified, she doesn't have the judgment, to be next in line to the president of the United States," said Persily in August 2008.<ref name=Palin />
In December 2009, Democratic Senator [[Mark Begich]] recommended Persily for the Obama administration post.<ref>AP, "Begich Comments on Larry Persily as U.S. Pipeline Coordinator; President accepts Begich recommendation for important post," December 29, 2009. Found at [http://apradio.org/begich-comments-on-larry-persily-as-u-s-pipeline-coordinator-president-accepts-begich-recommendation-for-important-post/ 830AM KSDP Radio News] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110811154229/http://apradio.org/begich-comments-on-larry-persily-as-u-s-pipeline-coordinator-president-accepts-begich-recommendation-for-important-post/ |date=2011-08-11 }}. Accessed September 12, 2010.</ref>
Persily was also a "key aide" to Alaska house member [[Mike Hawker]].<ref name=Forgey />
==See also== * [[Energy law]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110904073906/http://www.arcticgas.gov/ Alaska Natural Gas Transportation Projects government website] * [http://energy.senate.gov/public/_files/PersilyConfirmationTestimony.pdf Statement of Larry Persily Nominee for the position of Federal Coordinator Office of the Federal Coordinator for Alaska Natural Gas Transportation Projects Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee on February 2, 2010]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Persily, Larry}} [[Category:Energy law]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Obama administration personnel]] [[Category:People from Anchorage, Alaska]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]]

revision.comment: rv to last good revision before unsourced additions and atrocious grammar
revision.text:
[[File:Bermuda hurricane landfalls map.png|thumb|right|300px|Map depicting the paths of all [[landfall]]ing tropical cyclones in the territory since 1851|alt=Regional map showing the paths of nine tropical cyclones, all converging on Bermuda]] The [[British Overseas Territory]] of [[Bermuda]] has a long history of encounters with [[Atlantic hurricane|Atlantic tropical cyclones]], many of which inflicted significant damage and influenced the territory's development. A small [[archipelago]] comprising about 138 islands and islets, Bermuda occupies {{convert|21|sqmi|sqkm}} in the North Atlantic Ocean, roughly {{convert|650|mi|km}} east of [[Cape Hatteras, North Carolina]].<ref>{{cite web|title=The World Factbook: Bermuda|date=January 20, 2016|publisher=[[Central Intelligence Agency]]|accessdate=February 4, 2016|url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/bd.html}}</ref> The islands are situated far outside the main development region for Atlantic hurricanes,<ref name="elsner233">Elsner and Kara, p. 233</ref> but within the typical belt of [[Westerlies#Interaction with tropical cyclones|recurving]] tropical cyclones.<ref name="list">{{cite web|author1=Mark Guishard |author2=James Dodgson |author3=Michael Johnston |date=April 2016|title=Hurricanes – General Information for Bermuda|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|url=http://www.weather.bm/tropicalArchiveDocuments/Summary%20And%20Miscellaneous/Tropical%20Climatology%20-%20Timeline.docx|accessdate=October 26, 2016}}</ref> Most storms form in the central Atlantic or western Caribbean Sea before approaching Bermuda from the southwest; storms forming north of 28°N are unlikely to impact the territory.<ref name="elsner234">Elsner and Kara, p. 234</ref>
According to the [[Bermuda Weather Service]], the islands of Bermuda experience a damaging tropical cyclone once every six to seven years, on average.<ref name="list"/> Due to the small area of the island chain, [[landfall]]s and direct hits are rare.<ref name="list"/> Strictly speaking, only nine landfalls have occurred during years included in the official [[HURDAT|Atlantic hurricane database]], starting in 1851.{{hurdat}} When hurricanes [[Hurricane Fay (2014)|Fay]] and [[Hurricane Gonzalo|Gonzalo]] struck Bermuda just days apart in October 2014, that season became the first to produce two landfalls. Two damaging storms impacted Bermuda in September 1899, but the center of the first storm narrowly missed the islands.<ref name="gonzalotcr"/> Tropical cyclones, and their antecedent or remnant weather systems, have affected the territory in all seasons, most frequently in the late summer months.<ref name="list"/> A study of recorded storms from 1609 to 1996 found that direct hits from hurricanes were most common in early September and late October, with an intervening relative lull creating two distinct 'seasons'.<ref name="elsner236"/>
Hurricanes late in the year are often in the process of undergoing [[extratropical cyclone|extratropical transition]] and receiving [[baroclinicity|baroclinic enhancement]].<ref name="elsner236">Elsner and Kara, p. 236</ref> Bermuda is less likely to be impacted during years when the Caribbean, Gulf of Mexico, and southeastern United States are favored targets.<ref name="list"/> Even in intense hurricanes, the islands tend to fare relatively well; ever since a cyclone in 1712 destroyed many wooden buildings, most structures have been built with stone walls and roofs, and are able to withstand severe winds. As a result, hurricane-related deaths have been uncommon since the early 18th century.<ref name="list"/> Ten storms have collectively caused 129 fatalities; 110 of them, or 85%, were the result of shipwrecks along the shore in [[1926 Havana–Bermuda hurricane|Hurricane "Ten"]] of 1926. [[Hurricane Fabian]] in 2003 was the only system in the [[weather satellite]] era to cause storm-related deaths.
In total, 186 events are listed,<!-- FIGURE LAST UPDATED AFTER BERYL--> with widely varying degrees of damage. A hurricane in 1609 was responsible for the first permanent settlement on Bermuda: in late July, the [[Jamestown, Virginia|Jamestown]]-bound, British ship ''[[Sea Venture]]'' nearly foundered in the storm and sought refuge on the islands, which the passengers found surprisingly hospitable. Hurricane Fabian was the most intense storm to impact the territory in modern times, though officially it did not make landfall, and was the only storm to have its name [[list of retired Atlantic hurricanes|retired]] for effects in Bermuda. The costliest storms were Fabian and Gonzalo, which caused about $300 million and $200–400 million in damage respectively (2003 and 2014 [[United States Dollar|USD]]). Accounting for inflation and continued development, Fabian would have likely wrought around $650 million in damage had it struck in 2014.<ref name="air">{{cite news|title=Modellers estimate $200m–$400m in insured losses from Gonzalo|date=October 22, 2014|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=May 15, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20141022/BUSINESS/141029866}}</ref> The most recent tropical cyclone to affect the islands was [[2018 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Chris|Tropical Storm Chris]] in July 2018.
{{TOC right}}
==List of storms==
===1543–1699=== *1543 – The year 1543 and indistinct initials are carved on a rock in the modern-day [[Spittal Pond Nature Reserve]], likely by the occupants of a Portuguese vessel that became separated from her fleet and driven aground in the summer months. Thirty sailors survive on Bermuda for about 60 days, during which time they construct a seaworthy craft from recovered timbers of their wrecked ship. Given the time of year, a tropical hurricane may be responsible for this incident.<ref>Tucker, p. 19</ref> *July 24, 1609 – A hurricane sets the stage for the British colonization of Bermuda when a ship bound for [[Jamestown, Virginia]], is caught in the storm and forced to steer aground. When a fleet of [[Virginia Company]] ships tasked with resupplying the failing Jamestown colony encounters the hurricane, the flagship, ''[[Sea Venture]]'', becomes separated from the other vessels and begins to take on water. The increasingly waterlogged ''Sea Venture'' battles the rough seas until July 28, when, just as the crew becomes resigned to their fate, Admiral [[George Somers|Sir George Somers]] spots the uninhabited rocky shores of Bermuda. To prevent the ship from sinking, Somers deliberately drives her onto the reefs about a half mile off the eastern coast. Using the ship's [[longboat]], all 150 settlers, as well as the crew, make it safely ashore.<ref name="tucker20">Tucker, pp. 20–23</ref> The so-called "Isle of Devils" proves far more hospitable than initially feared, with abundant food and resources. Two new ships, the ''Deliverance'' and the ''Patience'', are constructed, and nearly all of the ''Sea Venture's'' original occupants set sail for Jamestown. The Virginia Company administers the islands until the formation of the [[Somers Isles Company]] in 1615.<ref>{{cite web|title=1609- Colonization of Bermuda|publisher=University of Rhode Island|accessdate=December 11, 2015|url=http://www.hurricanescience.org/history/storms/pre1900s/1609/}}</ref> The tale of the ''Sea Venture'' inspired [[William Shakespeare]] to write ''[[The Tempest]]'', and the [[coat of arms of Bermuda]] features a prominent representation of the shipwreck.<ref name="tucker20"/> *July (?) 1612 – A hurricane destroys a recently constructed church.<ref>Tucker, p. 24</ref> *September 1615 – A severe hurricane strikes Bermuda <ref>Tucker, pp. 23–25</ref> *November 1619 – Two hurricanes strike Bermuda during the month, sinking at least one ship, uprooting large trees, ruining the entire winter corn crop, and destroying a wooden watchtower constructed seven years earlier.<ref name="list"/><ref name="TuckerNovember1619">Tucker, pp. 25–26</ref> The rapid succession of two hurricanes leaves the colony with a severe food shortage.<ref name="Tucker1620"/> *1620 – A hurricane flattens hastily built shacks, while two fishermen are lost at sea.<ref name="Tucker1620">Tucker, pp. 26</ref> *September 13, 1621 – The arrival of a supply ship into port is delayed by stormy conditions; by the time the vessel wrecks along the coast, some of her passengers have died of a rampant illness.<ref>Tucker, pp. 26–27</ref> *August 16, 1629 – The most damaging hurricane thus far in the colony's history destroys crops, several forts, a prison, and the rebuilt watchtower.<ref name="list"/> *October 20, 1639 – Two Spanish ships ground out in a hurricane; the occupants are brought ashore, and charged monthly accommodation fees until their departure the following February. The sailors claim that the Governor had prevented them from leaving the colony except by means of purchasing their own ship.<ref>Tucker, pp. 30–33</ref> *October 16, 1664 – A British ship blows aground in the midst of a storm.<ref>Tucker, pp. 33–34</ref> *August 24, 1669 – One ship is wrecked by a hurricane along the shore of [[Castle Island, Bermuda|Castle Island]], with five men lost, and another capsizes roughly {{convert|20|mi|km|abbr=on}} off [[Ireland Island, Bermuda|Ireland Island]].<ref name="tucker34"/> *1686 – Hurricane season leaves the Government House in a state of disrepair.<ref name="tucker34">Tucker, p. 34</ref>
===1700–1799=== *September 8, 1712 – A severe hurricane buffets Bermuda for eight hours, destroying most of the churches. The storm highlights the necessity of ongoing efforts to shift from wood construction to stone.<ref name="tucker36">Tucker, p. 36</ref> *1713 – By November, the effects of two hurricanes are evident, though the collective impact is less severe than that of the 1712 hurricane.<ref name="tucker36"/> *1715 – A disastrous hurricane destroys the rest of the wooden churches left standing after the 1712 hurricane.<ref name="tucker36"/> *1726 – A season of stormy weather includes two hurricane strikes in rapid succession. Private and public buildings alike are damaged by the hurricanes, and the persistent bad weather leads to a stream of stricken ships entering [[St. George's Harbour, Bermuda|St. George's Harbour]] for repairs. Without the support of the [[Somers Isles Company]], which was dissolved in 1684, impoverished colonists grow disillusioned; they are often unable to repair storm-related damage, the crops in 1726 are a complete loss, and the small supply of gunpowder is compromised.<ref>Tucker, pp. 36–37</ref> *1728 – The newly appointed [[Governor of Bermuda]], [[John Pitt (soldier)|John Pitt]], arrives to find the island in distress from a recent hurricane impact. The official residence requires repair once more.<ref>Tucker, p. 37</ref> *October 18, 1780 – After emerging from the [[Lesser Antilles]], where it establishes itself as the deadliest Atlantic hurricane on record, the [[Great Hurricane of 1780]] devastates Bermuda,<ref name="list"/> likely passing southeast of the islands.<ref name="pr">{{cite web|author=Orlando Pérez|year=1970|title=Notes on the Tropical Cyclones of Puerto Rico|publisher=San Juan, Puerto Rico National Weather Service|accessdate=December 2, 2015|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/data_sub/perez_11_20.pdf}}</ref> Some fifty ships are driven ashore with the [[storm surge]], and vast swaths of trees are uprooted; the town of St. George's is left with a "completely denuded air." Many homes are demolished. Famine and a [[smallpox]] epidemic take hold in the aftermath of the hurricane.<ref>Tucker, pp. 37–39</ref> *September 1786 – Houses are damaged and trees are uprooted by a hurricane, and the cotton crop is largely destroyed.<ref>Tucker, pp. 39–40</ref> *October 23, 1793 – A violent hurricane passes near the islands, causing "inconceivable" damage to homes and public buildings, many of them being totally destroyed. The storm topples several thousand trees and wreaks havoc on shipping; every vessel in St. George's Harbour is driven aground, many ships being wrecked or heavily damaged, and numerous wharves are lost. Most of the 40 or so [[fish pond]]s along the north shore of [[St. David's Island, Bermuda|St. David's Island]], with a cumulative capacity of about 5,000 fish, are destroyed.<ref>Tucker, pp. 40–42</ref>
===1800–1849=== *September 9–10, 1800 – The sloop ''John'' founders amid rough seas from a tropical storm or hurricane; her entire crew is rescued.<ref name="Tucker1800">Tucker, pp. 42–43</ref> Bermuda is subjected to a period of [[gale]]s but suffers no damage.<ref name="list"/> *November 4–5, 1800 – A hurricane brings strong winds to the islands, "destroying every shrub in its direction."<ref name="Tucker1800"/> Damage to trees and crops is substantial, and multiple vessels are driven ashore. This hurricane prompts a change in attitude toward the need for a lighthouse in Bermuda, and the establishment of a Marine Society is sought to aid families of sailors lost along the rocky coasts.<ref name="Tucker1800"/> *August 4–5, 1813 – Prior to this storm, St. George's Harbour becomes congested with numerous warships due to a [[War of 1812|war between Great Britain and the United States]]. Additionally, the economic aspect of this war leads to merchant vessels being detained within the harbour, further crowding the waters. A complete record of the number of ships does not exist, though at least 30 are believed to be present at the time of the hurricane. Around noon on August 4, a heavy squall affects the islands and winds steadily increase through the night. By early the following morning, winds roared at {{convert|90|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, tearing roofs from homes and ships from their moorings. There are violent collisions between vessels, described as a "horde of ships" by Master Joseph Hinson of the schooner Chapman, in the crowded harbour.<ref name="Tucker1813"/> Nearly every vessel is driven ashore or wrecked. Untold quantities of cargo are lost, with little to salvage. Despite the damage, only one life is lost aboard the [[ketch]] ''General Doyle''. In the storm's wake, construction begins on a new breakwater and other coastal installations.<ref name="Tucker1813">Tucker, pp. 44–46</ref> *October 15–19, 1814 – A hurricane strikes the islands "head-on," with persistent gale-force winds. Roads are clogged with debris and some homes are flooded, though damage is generally minor.<ref name="list"/><ref>Tucker, pp. 46–47</ref> *1815 – A slow-moving hurricane on an unspecified date batters the islands, altering the configuration of the coastline.<ref>Tucker, p. 48</ref> *August 1818 – A hurricane unroofs the Town Hall building on Front Street in Hamilton.<ref>Tucker, p. 49</ref> *September 19, 1828 – A hurricane to the northwest produces gale-force winds.<ref name="list"/> *June 6–7, 1832 – The center of a tropical cyclone passes over or very close to the islands.<ref name="list"/> Two schooners in St. George's Harbour are driven aground, and several houses are partially or totally unroofed. Tree damage is extensive.<ref>Tucker, pp. 50–51</ref> *September 11–12, 1839 – One of the worst storms in Bermuda's history strikes the islands from the south with an exceptional {{convert|11|ft|m|abbr=on}} storm surge.<ref name="list"/><ref>{{cite news|author=Edward Harris|title=Bermuda: To the hurricane born|date=February 10, 2011|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=December 1, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20100925/ISLAND/309259981}}</ref> Boats along the southern shore are carried ashore and deposited in fields,<ref name="reid443">Reid, p. 443</ref> while various species of fish are seen hundreds of yards inland.<ref>{{cite news|title=Violent hurricane at Bermuda|date=October 9, 1839|newspaper=Public Ledger|accessdate=December 1, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3742120/public_ledger/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> Hurricane-force winds uproot many thousands of trees and level numerous homes; few structures escape damage. Roadways are left impassable by debris from trees, walls, and fences. Many families are left homeless, some forced to abandon their homes in the middle of the night and endure the storm in the open. Sea spray renders nearly all residential wells brackish. Despite the destruction, no lives are reported lost.<ref>Tucker, pp. 53–56</ref> The storm is typically known as ''Reid's Hurricane'', after the newly appointed Bermuda Governor [[William Reid (British Army officer)|William Reid]] who studied and documented Atlantic hurricanes with great interest.<ref>{{cite news|author=Celia Palmer Curtis|title=Reid's Hurricane of September 1839|date=June 15, 2000|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=December 1, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20000615/ISLAND/306159966}}</ref> *October 21, 1841 – Hurricane-force winds from a nearby cyclone destroy a couple houses and damage several more, as well as destroying trees and food crops. Potato plants are left "as black and withered as if destroyed by a severe frost."<ref>Tucker, p. 57</ref> *October 8–9, 1842 – Winds increase to [[Beaufort scale|Force 9]] as a hurricane passes to the north.<ref>Ludlum, p. 149</ref> *August 18, 1843 – A small hurricane is distantly felt in the form of gusty winds.<ref name="list"/> *October 27, 1845 – The islands experience gale-force winds from a tropical cyclone to the east.<ref>Tucker, p. 58</ref> *September 17–18, 1846 – Squally weather and pounding surf indicate the passage of a hurricane to the south and west. Aside from damage to trees, no major destruction is reported.<ref>Tucker, pp. 58–59</ref> *October 15, 1848 – Violent winds and tides {{convert|3|to|4|ft}} from a nearby hurricane batter the islands. Many wharves are submerged or entirely washed away, while stone walls and part of a breakwater collapse from the force of the surge. Roadways and homes in [[Flatts Village, Bermuda|Flatts Village]] are also flooded.<ref>Tucker, pp. 59–60</ref>
===1850–1899=== *September 6–8, 1853 – The outer fringes of a [[1853 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Three|major hurricane]] are felt in the islands, but no damage is reported.<ref name="tucker61"/> *September 26–27, 1853 – A [[1853 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Six|tropical cyclone]] to the east produces gale-force winds and heavy rainfall.<ref name="tucker61">Tucker, p. 61</ref> *October 21, 1854 – A [[1854 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Five|tropical storm]] passes a short distance to the southeast with Force 11 winds. "Great" property damage is reported, particularly at [[Spanish Point, Bermuda|Spanish Point]], and numerous boats are destroyed. Observers witness two possible tornadoes: one that passes over [[Boaz Island, Bermuda|Boaz Island]], scouring the ground, and another in eastern [[Paget Parish]] that topples trees and unroofs a home.<ref>Tucker, p. 62</ref> *October 23–24, 1858 – The center of a [[1858 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Six|moderate hurricane]] passes near the islands with powerful winds and flooding tides. The storm damages many homes and churches, and uproots a large number of trees.<ref>Tucker, p. 62–63</ref> *October 4, 1866 – Force 11 winds are reported on the outer fringes of a distant [[1866 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Six|hurricane]]. Buildings sustain roof and wall damage, trees are toppled, and several boats are damaged or wrecked.<ref name="Tucker, p. 64">Tucker, p. 64</ref> *September 10, 1870 – A [[1870 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Four|major hurricane]] to the northwest blows down a large number of banana trees.<ref name="Tucker, p. 64"/> [[File:Floating Dock BERMUDA Tafel3.jpg|right|thumb|The floating dry dock ''Bermuda'', heavily damaged in an August 1878 hurricane, is shown being towed to Bermuda in 1869|alt=A large, U-shaped vessel, on the high seas, being towed by a sailing ship.]]
*September 5, 1874 – A [[1874 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Three|hurricane]] to the west generates huge swells as sea spray defoliates plants across the territory.<ref>Tucker, p. 65</ref> *October 20–23, 1876 – Gale-force winds and heavy rainfall mark the passage of a [[1876 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|hurricane]] to the north.<ref>{{cite web|page=58|author=José F. Partagás|year=1995|title=A Reconstruction of Historical Tropical Cyclone Frequency in the Atlantic from Documentary and other Historical Sources: Year 1876|publisher=Atlantic Oceanographic & Meteorological Laboratory|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/Partagas/1871-1876/1876.pdf|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> *August 27–28, 1878 – Streets are clogged with fallen trees as a [[1878 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Four|hurricane]] passes to the north.<ref name="tucker67">Tucker, pp. 67–68</ref> At the height of a storm, a [[floating dry dock]]—the largest ever built at the time<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20120728/NEWS/707289997&source=RSS|author=Samantha Alves|title= History-making floating dock reaches 143rd anniversary|date=July 28, 2012|accessdate=November 28, 2015|newspaper=The Royal Gazette}}</ref>—is damaged after breaking from its moorings at HM Dockyard, crushing wharves and a mooring bridge. The dock came to rest on a [[breakwater (structure)|breakwater]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Furious Hurricane at Bermuda|date=November 28, 2015|newspaper=The New York Times|accessdate=November 28, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3720205/the_new_york_times/}}</ref>
*August 29–30, 1880 – A slow-moving [[1880 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|hurricane]], locally cited as the most severe since 1839, makes its closest approach approximately {{convert|40|mi|km|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} to the northeast.<ref name="list"/> Intense winds cause "vast" damage to buildings and vegetation, particularly in eastern parts of the islands. A newly built school is destroyed in [[Smith's Parish]], and the Causeway sustains significant damage.<ref name="tucker69">Tucker, pp. 69–71</ref><ref name="times">{{cite news|title=Storm in Bermuda|date=September 9, 1880|newspaper=The Times-Picayune|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3719930/the_timespicayune/|accessdate=November 28, 2015|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> Several ships are driven aground, and dozens of smaller boats are wrecked.<ref name="times"/> Fruit crops are a total loss.<ref>{{cite news|title=A Terrible Hurricane|date=September 9, 1880|newspaper=Chicago Daily Tribune|accessdate=November 28, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3719958/chicago_daily_tribune/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> *October 14, 1880 – Blustery squalls are reported along the fringe of a [[1880 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Ten|hurricane]] to the southeast.<ref name="part1880">{{cite web|pages=67–68, 78|author=José F. Partagás|year=1995|title=A Reconstruction of Historical Tropical Cyclone Frequency in the Atlantic from Documentary and other Historical Sources: Year 1880|publisher=Atlantic Oceanographic & Meteorological Laboratory|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/Partagas/1877-1880/1880.pdf|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> *August 28, 1891 – Heavy squalls and winds to Force 6 indicate the passage of a [[1891 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|hurricane]] to the east.<ref name="part1891"/> The storm damages trees, telegraph wires, and stone walls.<ref>{{cite news|title=A hurricane in Bermuda|date=August 30, 1891|newspaper=Los Angeles Harold|accessdate=December 17, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3842085/los_angeles_herald/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> *September 19–22, 1891 – A slow-moving [[1891 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|Category 2 hurricane]] approaches from the east and recurves just before the islands. High winds bring down trees and utility wires,<ref>{{cite news|title=Storm in Bermuda|date=September 22, 1891|newspaper=The London Times|accessdate=November 24, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3698272/the_times/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> and a Spanish brig loaded with lumber wrecks along the southwestern shore.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=North Atlantic Storms for September, 1981|journal=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=American Meteorological Society|date=September 1891|volume=19|issue=9|pages=212–213|accessdate=November 24, 2015|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/1520-0493%281891%2919%5B212%3ANASFSP%5D2.0.CO%3B2|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1891)19[212:NASFSP]2.0.CO;2|bibcode= 1891MWRv...19..212.}}</ref> *October 4, 1891 – A [[1891 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Six|moderate hurricane]] to the west produces a prolonged period of strong winds and heavy rain,<ref name="part1891"/> but no appreciable damage is reported.<ref name="tucker72">Tucker, p. 72</ref> *October 17–18, 1891 – A [[1891 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Nine|hurricane]] passes a short distance to the west with extremely high tides and pounding waves.<ref name="list"/><ref name="part1891">{{cite web|pages=74–77|author=José F. Partagás|year=1996|title=A Reconstruction of Historical Tropical Cyclone Frequency in the Atlantic from Documentary and other Historical Sources: Year 1891|publisher=Atlantic Oceanographic & Meteorological Laboratory|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/Partagas/1891-1893/1891.pdf|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> The Causeway is extensively damaged.<ref name="tucker72"/> *August 19–20, 1892 – Though winds are relatively light, a [[1892 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|hurricane]] to the west causes some agricultural, structural, and maritime damage.<ref>Tucker, pp. 73–74</ref> *October 15, 1892 – Winds just below hurricane force are recorded at the [[Gibbs Hill Lighthouse]] as a [[1892 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Eight|hurricane]] passes to the east.<ref name="list"/> *October 26, 1894 – A [[1894 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Seven|fast-moving hurricane]] to the west delivers a brief period of hurricane-force winds, toppling trees and telephone poles. The storm blows down roofing material and ruins vegetable crops.<ref>Tucker, pp. 74–75</ref> *October 24, 1895 – Wind gusts of {{convert|120|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} are reported in association with a direct hit from a [[1895 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|moderate hurricane]].<ref name="list"/> Dozens of telephone poles are snapped, while "enormous" trees are uprooted. Extensive damage befalls homes, businesses, and public buildings.<ref>Tucker, pp. 77–78</ref> *September 4, 1899 – A [[1899 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Four|Category 1 hurricane]] passes just to the northwest, producing hurricane-force winds and significant damage.<ref>{{cite web|pages=74–77|author=José F. Partagás|year=1996|title=A Reconstruction of Historical Tropical Cyclone Frequency in the Atlantic from Documentary and other Historical Sources: Year 1899 (part 2)|publisher=Atlantic Oceanographic & Meteorological Laboratory|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/Partagas/1898-1900/1899_2.pdf|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> *September 12–13, 1899 – The distinct eye of a [[1899 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|Category 3 hurricane]] tracks over Bermuda with severe damage reported in many areas.<ref name="part1899"/> As residents are preoccupied with cleanup efforts from the previous storm, the hurricane catches the islands off-guard.<ref name="tucker76">Tucker, pp. 76–80</ref> Houses are unroofed or completely destroyed, and large boulders along the southern shore are tossed inland. Wharves and boats are wrecked. HM Dockyard in particular takes heavy losses, amounting to "at least five figures" ([[Pound sterling|GBP]]).<ref name="part1899">{{cite web|pages=74–77|author=José F. Partagás|year=1996|title=A Reconstruction of Historical Tropical Cyclone Frequency in the Atlantic from Documentary and other Historical Sources: Year 1899 (part 3)|publisher=Atlantic Oceanographic & Meteorological Laboratory|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/Landsea/Partagas/1898-1900/1899_3.pdf|accessdate=December 2, 2015}}</ref> St. George's Parish is cut off from the mainland after the Causeway is demolished by strong waves, at a cost of around £15,000. The hurricane also extensively damages crops and vegetation, dealing a major blow to farmers.<ref name="tucker76"/> Early estimates place total property damage at £100,000,<ref>{{cite news|title=Cyclone at Bermuda|date=September 14, 1899|newspaper=The Wilmington Morning Star|accessdate=December 17, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3842032/the_wilmington_morning_star/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> and this storm remains the strongest on record to impact the islands until [[1926 Havana–Bermuda hurricane|Hurricane Ten]] of 1926.<ref name="metadata"/>
===1900s=== *September 17, 1900 – Strong winds from a [[1900 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|hurricane]] to the east cause little damage.<ref name="list"/> *September 28, 1903 – A [[1903 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Six|Category 2 hurricane]] passing a short distance to the east causes significant damage. Winds of {{convert|74|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} uproot large numbers of trees, while heavy rainfall washes out roadways. Along the coast, docks, seawalls, and boats are destroyed;<ref name="tucker85">Tucker, pp. 85–87</ref> hundreds of buildings throughout the islands are damaged.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hurricane at Bermuda|date=October 2, 1903|newspaper=The New Berne Weekly Journal|accessdate=November 22, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3680116/new_berne_weekly_journal/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> Two fatalities are attributed to the storm: one man drowns at [[Ireland Island, Bermuda|Ireland Island]], and another is crushed by a collapsing wall in St. George's.<ref name="tucker85"/> *September 8–9, 1906 – A [[1906 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Four|major hurricane]] to the northwest brushes the islands with {{convert|70|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} winds, blowing down roof slates, telephone wires, and trees. One man drowns after being blown off [[Watford Bridge]], and another fatality occurs in Hamilton Harbour as a sailboat capsizes in a severe squall.<ref>Tucker, pp. 87–88</ref> A ferry in the harbour is destroyed by fire, which briefly threatens to spread to land.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bermuda Gale Rages, Kills|date=September 10, 1906|newspaper=The Chicago Tribune Daily|accessdate=November 21, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3678128/chicago_daily_tribune/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> *October 13, 1909 – A dissipating [[1909 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Eleven|tropical storm]] produces strong winds.<ref name="Tucker, p. 88">Tucker, p. 88</ref>
===1910s=== [[File:1915 Atlantic hurricane 3 track.png|right|thumb|Track of the September 1915 major hurricane that buffeted Bermuda for several days|alt=Map showing the path and intensity of the September 1915 hurricane]] *September 25, 1910 – A [[1910 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Four|moderate hurricane]] to the east damages buildings in St. George's, topples a few banana trees, and blows a ship aground. Heavy rains provide residents with many months of clean drinking water.<ref name="Tucker, p. 88"/> *September 3–8, 1915 – A [[1915 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Three|Category 3 hurricane]] meanders around the islands for several days, during which time gale-force winds blow from nearly all directions.<ref name="metadata"/> Heavy rains cause many roofs to leak, and overall damage is extensive. Enormous waves from the hurricane wreck many boats; one cargo ship in particular, the SS ''Pollockshields'', is driven aground on a reef off Elbow Beach. The captain drowns while attempting to procure a life jacket for a crew member, but all other men are eventually rescued.<ref>Tucker, pp. 90–95</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Historical Photos: Boat Passengers Escape in 1915|date=October 18, 2010|newspaper=Bernews|accessdate=November 21, 2015|url=http://bernews.com/2010/10/historical-photos-boat-passengers-escape-in-1915/}}</ref> *September 23, 1916 – A [[1916 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Eleven|major hurricane]] just to the west brings winds of at least {{convert|84|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. The storm, considered the most severe in many years, damages most structures, with several being nearly or completely destroyed. Exposed buildings along Front Street in Hamilton bear the brunt of the hurricane.<ref>Tucker, pp. 95–99</ref> Numerous small boats in Hamilton Harbour are wrecked.<ref name="list"/> *September 4, 1917 – Enormous waves and extremely high tides from a [[1917 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Three|major hurricane]] to the east inundate low-lying areas, including the entirety of Market Square in St. George's; individuals at Town Hall become stranded by the rising waters. A large section of [[Higgs' Island, Bermuda|Higgs' Island]] is swept away.<ref>Tucker, p. 99</ref> *September 4–5, 1918 – The center of a [[1918 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|Category 2 hurricane]] passes narrowly to the west, sinking or grounding boats and flooding parts of the islands. Winds of at least {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} topple trees and shatter windows.<ref>Tucker, p. 100</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=General Forecast|date=September 5, 1918|newspaper=The Washington Herald|accessdate=November 21, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3673583/the_washington_herald/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref>
===1920s=== *September 15, 1921 – A high-end [[1921 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Three|Category 2 hurricane]] inflicts severe damage on trees, public utilities, and small boats while striking the island. Many buildings – including several hotels – suffer damage, mostly of a minor nature.<ref name="tucker101">Tucker, pp. 101–102</ref> Wind gusts as high as {{convert|120|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} are recorded at Prospect Hill before the anemometer is toppled.<ref name="metadata"/><ref name="tucker101"/> Water wells become contaminated by the sea spray.<ref name="tucker101"/> *September 21, 1922 – Bermuda is struck by a [[1922 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|Category 3 hurricane]] and associated {{convert|8|ft|m|abbr=on}} storm surge, resulting in the highest tide since 1899. The hurricane submerges homes, roads, wharves, and other coastal installations, while {{convert|60|ft|m|abbr=on}} waves break along the south shore. Winds reaching {{convert|120|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} ravage vegetation, particularly banana trees. Heavy structural damage is also reported throughout the territory, and a number of small houses on White's Island are blown into the water.<ref name="tucker103">Tucker, p. 103</ref> Total damage is estimated at $250,000,<ref>{{cite news|title=Cyclone Does Great Damage|date=September 28, 1922|newspaper=Shiner Gazette|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3671635/shiner_gazette/|accessdate=November 20, 2015|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> and one fatality occurs when a sailor falls overboard at the Dockyard.<ref name="tucker103"/>
[[File:The Loss of the Valerian.JPG|right|thumb|Artist's impression of the sinking of the ''Valerian'' at Bermuda in October 1926|alt=Sketch of an imperiled sloop cresting over a large wave in stormy weather]] *September 23, 1923 – A major hurricane to the northwest brings winds of {{convert|62|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} with gusts to {{convert|90|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="list"/> Parts of St. George's are inundated with seawater, and cottages on St. David's Island are damaged. The storm brings down trees, tree branches, and powerlines.<ref>Tucker, p. 106</ref> *August 6, 1926 – A [[1926 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|Category 2 hurricane]] tracks about {{convert|80|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the west, causing winds to increase to {{convert|54|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="metadata"/> A few small boats in harbour are swamped.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Near Hurricane is Sweeping Bermuda|date=August 6, 1926|newspaper=The Hutchison News|accessdate=November 20, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3670812/the_hutchinson_news/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> *October 22, 1926 – A [[1926 Havana–Bermuda hurricane|Category 3 hurricane]] makes landfall,<ref name="list"/> becoming tied with [[1899 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|Hurricane Five]] of 1899 for the strongest recorded storm to strike the territory.<ref name="metadata"/> The second half of the cyclone is the most violent, with sustained winds of {{convert|114|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at Fort Prospect and gusts over {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} recorded in Hamilton.<ref name="list"/><ref name="metadata"/> Damage is widespread but not extreme; although 40% of Bermuda's houses sustain roof damage, only two are demolished.<ref>{{cite journal|author=W. H. Potter|title=Hurricane at Bermuda, October 22, 1926|date=October 1926|journal=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=American Meteorological Society|volume=54|issue=10|page=428|accessdate=November 20, 2015|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/1520-0493%281926%2954%3C428a%3AHABO%3E2.0.CO%3B2|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1926)54<428a:HABO>2.0.CO;2|bibcode= 1926MWRv...54Q.428.}}</ref> The storm destroys banana plantations and fields of other crops.<ref name="tucker107">Tucker, p. 107</ref> The [[Arabis-class sloop|''Arabis''-class]] warship HMS ''Valerian'' sinks less than {{convert|5|mi|km|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} from HM Dockyard with 88 men lost and 21 survivors. Another ship, the cargo steamer SS ''Eastway'', is lost near Bermuda along with 22 of her 35 crew members.<ref>{{cite news|title=1926 Bermuda Hurricane Sank UK Warship|date=June 2, 2013|newspaper=Bernews|accessdate=November 20, 2015|url=http://bernews.com/2013/06/1926-bermuda-hurricane-sank-uk-warship/}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Edward Harris|title=October Surprise|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|date=October 20, 2012|accessdate=November 20, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20121020/ISLAND09/710209952}}</ref>
===1930s=== *November 12, 1932 – A [[1932 Cuba hurricane|Category 2 hurricane]] passes about {{convert|80|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the southeast, generating gusts to {{convert|87|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="list"/> *August 21, 1933 – As a [[1933 Chesapeake–Potomac hurricane|major hurricane]] passes to the southwest, winds increase to {{convert|64|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="metadata"/> The slow-moving storm delays the arrival of ships into port.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Storms Batter Eastern Coast Claiming Toll|newspaper=The Kokomo Tribune|date=August 22, 1933|accessdate=November 19, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3664518/the_kokomo_tribune/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> *October 6, 1933 – A [[1933 Cuba–Bahamas hurricane|hurricane]] passes to the northwest, delivering gale-force winds.<ref name="metadata"/> *November 25, 1934 – Gale-force winds accompany a slow-moving [[1934 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Thirteen|hurricane]] to the south.<ref name="metadata"/> *August 23, 1935 – A [[1935 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Two|Category 3 hurricane]] narrowly misses to the northwest, with relatively light winds reported.<ref name="metadata"/> *June 17, 1936 – The season's [[1936 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm One|first tropical storm]] produces gusty winds while passing just to the north.<ref name="metadata"/> *October 16, 1939 – A [[1939 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Five|Category 4 hurricane]] passes a short distance to the east, causing torrential rain – {{convert|7.35|in|mm|abbr=on}} – and wind gusts as high as {{convert|131|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. Boats, homes, and vegetation all suffer considerable damage.<ref name="list"/>
===1940s=== *August 26, 1942 – A [[1942 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Four|Category 2 hurricane]] passes about {{convert|100|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the east; winds reach {{convert|64|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} in Bermuda.<ref name="metadata"/> *September 28, 1942 – A [[1942 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Seven|tropical storm]] curves around Bermuda with marginal tropical storm-force winds.<ref name="metadata"/> *October 3, 1942 – Winds blow around {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} as a [[1942 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Eight|tropical storm]] passes to the east.<ref name="metadata"/> *August 24, 1943 – A [[1943 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Four|major hurricane]] passes to the west, delivering a period of hurricane-force winds to Bermuda.<ref name="metadata"/> *September 3–4, 1943 – Winds to {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} accompany the outer fringes of [[1943 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Four|a hurricane]] to the east.<ref name="metadata"/> *October 1, 1943 – A [[1943 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Eight|tropical storm]] curves to the west, producing gusty winds.<ref name="metadata"/> *October 16–17, 1943 – A weakening [[1943 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Ten|hurricane]] to the west causes gale-force winds.<ref name="metadata"/> *July 18, 1944 – Winds around {{convert|40|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} are observed as a [[1944 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane One|tropical storm]] passes to the northwest.<ref name="metadata">{{cite news|author=Chris Landsea |title=Documentation of Atlantic Tropical Cyclones Changes in HURDAT |year=2015 |publisher=National Hurricane Center |agency=Hurricane Research Division |accessdate=November 19, 2015 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/metadata_master.html |display-authors=etal |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110604063810/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/hrd/hurdat/metadata_master.html |archivedate=June 4, 2011 |df= }}</ref>
[[File:Hurricane Dog (1948) analysis 13 Sep.png|right|thumb|[[Surface weather analysis]] of the September 1948 hurricane on its approach to Bermuda|alt=Refer to caption]] *October 20, 1947 – A [[1947 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Ten (Love)|Category 3 hurricane]] reaches its peak intensity about {{convert|60|mi|km|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} to the west, producing damaging winds in excess of {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite journal|author=H. C. Sumner|title=North Atlantic Hurricanes and Tropical Disturbances of 1947|journal=Monthly Weather Review|date=December 1947|publisher=American Meteorological Society|volume=75|issue=12|pages=251–255|accessdate=November 19, 2015|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/1520-0493%281947%29075%3C0251%3ANAHATD%3E2.0.CO%3B2|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1947)075<0251:NAHATD>2.0.CO;2|bibcode=1947MWRv...75..251S}}</ref> The hurricane cuts electric and telephone services, and numerous boats are sunk, including a ferry outside Hamilton Harbour. Homes are unroofed and trees are blown down, while ten people are slightly injured.<ref>{{cite news|title=Bermuda Hit by Hurricane|date=October 21, 1947|newspaper=The Marysville Tribune|accessdate=November 19, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3660729/the_marysville_tribune/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref><ref name="ogden">{{cite news|author=United Press|title=Hurricane Sinks Bermuda Boats|date=October 21, 1947|newspaper=The Ogden Standard-Examiner|accessdate=November 19, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3660738/the_ogden_standardexaminer/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> Preliminary estimates place damage at $1 million.<ref name="ogden"/> In the aftermath of the storm, a lineman is killed after falling from a pole during service restoration efforts.<ref>Tucker, p. 121</ref> *September 13, 1948 – A [[1948 Bermuda–Newfoundland hurricane|Category 3 hurricane]] passes roughly {{convert|50|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the west, battering Bermuda with {{convert|80|to|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} winds and gusts to {{convert|135|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}. Roadways are clogged with various debris, and St. George's is cut off from the mainland.<ref name="list"/><ref>Tucker, p. 123</ref> Meanwhile, some buildings are deroofed. Rainfall totaling nearly {{convert|5|in|mm|abbr=on}} triggers street flooding.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Bermuda Clearing Debris; Hurricane to Miss U.S. Coast|date=September 14, 1948|newspaper=The Spokane Daily Chronicle|accessdate=November 19, 2015|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=tPFXAAAAIBAJ&sjid=vfUDAAAAIBAJ&pg=7325,5238596&dq=hurricane&hl=en}}</ref> *October 7, 1948 – The territory encounters a direct hit from a [[1948 Miami hurricane|Category 2 hurricane]], with gusts measured at {{convert|110|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="list"/><ref name="tucker124">Tucker, p. 124</ref> The storm uproots thousands of trees and leaves the entire territory without power.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Heavy Damage to Bermuda in Hurricane|date=October 8, 1948|newspaper=Nashua Telegraph|accessdate=November 19, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3660403/nashua_telegraph/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> Many buildings suffered roof or wall damage; total losses are estimated at $1 million.<ref name="tucker124"/><ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Million Damage Done by Bermuda Hurricane|date=October 10, 1948|newspaper=The Bridgeport Telegram|accessdate=November 19, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3660431/the_bridgeport_telegram/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> *September 8, 1949 – A [[1949 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Four|Category 3 hurricane]] passes about {{convert|60|mi|km|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} to the west, though winds in Bermuda remain below hurricane-force.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://journals.ametsoc.org/doi/abs/10.1175/1520-0493%281949%29077%3C0339%3ANAHATD%3E2.0.CO%3B2|author=Richmond T. Zoch|title=North Atlantic Hurricanes and Tropical Disturbances of 1949|date=December 1949|journal=Monthly Weather Review|volume=77|issue=12|pages=339–342|publisher=American Meteorological Society|accessdate=November 19, 2015|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1949)077<0339:NAHATD>2.0.CO;2|bibcode=1949MWRv...77..339Z}}</ref> A few tree limbs are broken.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Atlantic Hurricane Lashes Bermuda Coast|date=September 9, 1949|newspaper=The Joplin Globe|accessdate=November 19, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3660343/joplin_globe/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref>
===1950s=== * September 8, 1950 – Winds near {{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} mark the approach of [[Hurricane Dog (1950)|Hurricane Dog]] from the southwest.<ref name="list"/> * October 2, 1950 – Category 2 [[Hurricane George (1950)|Hurricane George]] passes about {{convert|100|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the south, producing tropical storm-force winds.<ref name="list"/> * September 9, 1951 – As [[Hurricane Easy (1951)|Hurricane Easy]] passes to the southeast, gusty winds blow down several banana trees.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Two Hurricanes Collide at Sea; Bermuda Spared|date=September 10, 1951|newspaper=The San Bernardino County Sun|accessdate=November 19, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3659743/the_san_bernardino_county_sun/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> * September 27, 1952 – [[Hurricane Charlie (1952)|Hurricane Charlie]] passes to the northwest, resulting in a period of tropical storm-force winds.<ref name="list"/> * September 5, 1953 – Winds near {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} accompany the outer bands of [[Hurricane Carol (1953)|Hurricane Carol]] to the southwest.<ref name="list"/> The squalls knock down tree limbs and powerlines and injure two motorcyclists, while two motorocyclists in Hamilton are injured after being blown off-balance.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Storm Warnings are up from Jersey to Maine|date=September 7, 1953|newspaper=The St. Petersburgh Times|accessdate=November 19, 2015|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=zJ9aAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Nk8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5242,2421463&dq=hurricane+carol+northeast&hl=en}}</ref> * September 11–12, 1953 – [[Hurricane Dolly (1953)|Tropical Storm Dolly]] makes landfall, but the weakening storm causes little damage. Gale-force winds and moderate rainfall disrupt telephone service.<ref name="list"/><ref>Tucker, p. 130</ref> * September 17, 1953 – Category 3 [[Hurricane Edna (1953)|Hurricane Edna]] passes about {{convert|50|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the northwest with torrential rains and gusts to around {{convert|120|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="list"/> The winds cause significant damage to homes and trees, and some freshwater flooding is reported. Edna also wreaks havoc on boats in [[Hamilton Harbour, Bermuda|Hamilton Harbour]] and disrupts water and power utilities across Bermuda. Three people sustain storm-related injuries.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Hurricane Edna Lashes Bermuda|date=September 18, 1953|newspaper=The Atchison Daily Globe|accessdate=November 18, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3657856/the_atchison_daily_globe/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref><ref>Tucker, p. 131</ref> * September 28, 1958 – [[Hurricane Ilsa (1958)|Hurricane Ilsa]] to the east causes squally conditions and extensive beach erosion.<ref>Tucker, p. 132</ref>
===1960s=== *October 7, 1961 – Category 3 [[Hurricane Frances (1961)|Hurricane Frances]] passes about {{convert|100|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the northwest, with its effects limited to rough seas and light rainfall.<ref name="list"/> *October 6, 1962 – [[Hurricane Daisy (1962)|Hurricane Daisy]] to the west results in wind gusts to {{convert|66|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and heavy surf.<ref name="list"/> *August 9, 1963 – Category 1 [[Hurricane Arlene (1963)|Hurricane Arlene]] makes landfall and produces torrential rain totaling {{convert|6.05|in|mm|abbr=on}}.<ref name="hpc"/> Gusts to {{convert|98|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} cause extensive tree damage, enabled by a dearth of recent storms,<ref name="list"/><ref name="arlenetcr">{{cite journal|author=Gordon E. Dunn |title=The Hurricane Season of 1963 |journal=Monthly Weather Review |publisher=American Meteorological Society |page=130 |volume=92 |issue=3 |date=March 1964 |accessdate=November 11, 2015 |url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1963.pdf |bibcode=1964MWRv...92..128D |doi=10.1175/1520-0493-92.3.128 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090507122057/http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1963.pdf |archivedate=May 7, 2009 |df= }}</ref> and further foliage is killed by the sea spray. Heavy losses are reported to citrus and avocado crops.<ref>Tucker, p. 139</ref> Arlene destroys homes and watercraft, and a yacht club in [[Devonshire Parish]] is "wiped out in its entirety including every boat."<ref name="began">{{cite news|author=Tricia Walters |title= It began with a hurricane 400 years ago...|date=July 9, 2009|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=November 11, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20090709/SUPPLEMENT/307099970}}</ref> Property damage is estimated at $300,000.<ref name="arlenetcr"/>
*August 8, 1964 – [[Tropical Storm Brenda (1964)|Tropical Storm Brenda]] makes landfall, spawning a tornado that damages several airplanes. A {{convert|92|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} wind gust recorded by an elevated anemometer is attributed to the tornado.<ref>{{cite web|title=Tropical Storm Brenda – August 8-10, 1964|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 18, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1964/brenda/prenhc/prelim01.gif}}</ref> [[File:Inga 1969 track.png|right|thumb|[[Hurricane Inga (1969)|Hurricane Inga]], one of the longest-lived Atlantic tropical cyclones on record, brushed the territory in October 1969|alt=Map showing the path and intensity of Hurricane Inga]]
*September 12–13, 1964 – Category 2 [[Hurricane Ethel (1964)|Hurricane Ethel]] passes about {{convert|90|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the northwest, bringing wind gusts near hurricane force and heavy rain, totaling {{convert|4.05|in|mm|abbr=on}}.<ref name="list"/> Power and telephone services are interrupted on St. George's, and the Causeway experiences overwash.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Dora Dumps Heavy Rain On Carolinas|date=September 14, 1964|newspaper=The Cumberland News|accessdate=November 18, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3613979/the_cumberland_news/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> *July 20–21, 1966 – [[Hurricane Celia (1966)|Hurricane Celia]] to the west douses Bermuda with heavy but beneficial rain.<ref>Tucker, p. 142</ref> *August 31 – September 2, 1966 – The outer bands of [[Hurricane Faith]] produce heavy rainfall and gusty winds.<ref name="list"/><ref>Tucker, p. 143</ref> *October 5, 1969 – Strong winds from [[Hurricane Inga (1969)|Hurricane Inga]] to the southeast cause brief power outages.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Hurricane Slams Into Bermuda|date=October 6, 1969|newspaper=San Antonio Express|accessdate=January 6, 2017|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/8204318/san_antonio_express/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref>
===1970s=== *October 16, 1970 – An [[1970 Canada hurricane|unnamed Category 1 hurricane]] skirts just to the west, with wind gusts as high as {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} measured by an elevated anemometer.<ref>{{cite journal|pages=969–974|author=David B. Spiegler|title=The unnamed Atlantic tropical storms of 1970|journal=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=American Meteorological Society|accessdate=November 11, 2015|url=http://docs.lib.noaa.gov/rescue/mwr/099/mwr-099-12-0966.pdf|volume=99|number=12|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1971)099<0966:tuatso>2.3.co;2|bibcode=1971MWRv...99..966S}}</ref> *September 23, 1971 – A long-duration wind event marks the passage of [[Hurricane Ginger]] to the south. [[Naval Air Station Bermuda]] observes 17 hours of gale-force winds, peaking at {{convert|75|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Ginger September 5 – October 5|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 11, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1971-prelim/ginger/prelim02.gif|page=2}}</ref> *July 4, 1973 – Category 1 [[Hurricane Alice (1973)|Hurricane Alice]] produces strong wind gusts and {{convert|4.57|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain as it passes about {{convert|20|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the west.<ref name="alicetcr">{{cite journal|author1=Paul J. Herbert |author2=Neil L. Frank |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1973|date=April 1974|journal=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=American Meteorological Society|pages=282–285|volume=102|issue=4|url=http://www.aoml.noaa.gov/general/lib/lib1/nhclib/mwreviews/1973.pdf|accessdate=November 11, 2015|bibcode=1974MWRv..102..280H|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1974)102<0280:AHSO>2.0.CO;2}}</ref> Despite blowing down a few trees and powerlines,<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Hurricane Alice Hits Bermuda|date=July 4, 1973|newspaper=The Aiken Standard|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3605840/aiken_standard/|accessdate=November 11, 2015|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> the storm proved beneficial, helping to alleviate persistent drought conditions.<ref name="list"/> *September 26–27, 1975 – Category 2 [[Hurricane Faye|Hurricane Fay]] passes about {{convert|40|mi|km|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} to the northeast, generating wind gusts to {{convert|69|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and dropping {{convert|2.8|in|m|abbr=on}} of rain.<ref name="list"/> *September 9, 1977 – Light rainfall accumulations are reported in association with [[Hurricane Clara (1977)|Tropical Storm Clara]].<ref name="hpc">{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Tropical Cyclone Point Maxima|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=November 11, 2015|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/tcmaxima.html}}</ref> *September 27, 1977 – [[Hurricane Dorothy (1977)|Tropical Storm Dorothy]] passes about {{convert|60|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the southeast, yielding {{convert|3.74|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain.<ref name="list"/> *October 14, 1977 – [[Hurricane Evelyn|Tropical Storm Evelyn]] makes landfall, but the strongest part of the storm remains offshore; Bermuda experiences {{convert|2.6|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain and only light winds.<ref name="hpc"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Hurricane Evelyn October 13–16, 1977|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 11, 2015|page=1|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1977-prelim/evelyn/prelim01.gif}}</ref> *September 15, 1978 – A subtropical storm, future-[[Tropical Storm Hope (1978)|Tropical Storm Hope]], brushes the island with light rain showers amounting to {{convert|1.07|in|mm|abbr=on}}.<ref name="hpc"/> *October 11, 1978 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Juliet (1978)|Tropical Storm Juliet]] combine with a non-tropical storm system to produce moderate rains.<ref>{{cite web|title=Preliminary Report: Tropical Storm Juliet|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 11, 2015|page=1|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1978-prelim/juliet/prelim01.gif}}</ref>
===1980s=== *September 2, 1981 – The center of [[Hurricane Emily (1981)|Tropical Storm Emily]] passes near the island, producing rough seas and {{convert|4.92|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain.<ref name="list"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Gil Clark|title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Emily|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 10, 2015|page=1|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1981-prelim/emily/prelim01.gif}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Bermuda feeling effects of storm|date=September 2, 1981|newspaper=The Index-Journal|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3597931/the_indexjournal/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> *September 8, 1981 – [[Hurricane Floyd (1981)|Hurricane Floyd]] weakens to a tropical storm and passes just southeast, placing Bermuda on the weaker side of the cyclone.<ref name="floydtcr">{{cite web|author=Joe Pellisier|title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Floyd|publisher=National Hurricane Center|page=1|accessdate=November 10, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1981-prelim/floyd/prelim01.gif}}</ref> The encounter yields only brief rain showers.<ref>{{cite news|author=Reuters|title=Bermuda threat fizzles as hurricane moves on|date=September 9, 1981|newspaper=The Globe and Mail|via=LexisNexis}}</ref> *September 16, 1982 – As Category 2 [[Hurricane Debby (1982)|Hurricane Debby]] passes about {{convert|80|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the west, wind gusts near {{convert|70|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} bring down a few trees and powerlines, but cause no major damage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Debby|publisher=National Hurricane Center|page=1|accessdate=November 10, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1982-prelim/debby/prelim01.gif}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Hurricane brushes past Bermuda|date=September 17, 1982|newspaper=The Galveston Daily News|accessdate=November 10, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3598345/the_galveston_daily_news/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}}</ref> *September 30, 1984 – The center of [[Hurricane Hortense (1984)|Tropical Storm Hortense]] passes a few miles to the west, with no significant effects.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lawrence Miles|title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Hortense|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 10, 2015|page=1|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1984-prelim/hortense/prelim01.gif}}</ref> *July 16, 1985 – [[Tropical Storm Ana (1985)|Tropical Storm Ana]] passes to the west, producing wind gusts to {{convert|47|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and heavy rain.<ref>{{cite web|title=Preliminary Report: Tropical Storm Ana|page=2|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 10, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1985-prelim/ana/prelim02.gif}}</ref> Some households lose electricity for several days.<ref>Tucker, p. 150</ref> *August 12, 1985 – [[Hurricane Claudette (1985)|Tropical Storm Claudette]] to the north causes gusty winds and light rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author=Harold P. Gerrish|title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Claudette|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 10, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1985-prelim/claudett/prelim01.gif|page=1}}</ref> *August 13, 1987 – Wind gusts to {{convert|50|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and {{convert|1.65|in|mm|abbr=on}} are reported in association with [[Hurricane Arlene (1987)|Tropical Storm Arlene]] about {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} to the north.<ref name="list"/><ref>{{cite web|author=Harold P. Gerrish|title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Arlene|page=1|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 10, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1987-prelim/arlene/prelim01.gif}}</ref> *September 25, 1987 – After a bout of unexpected and rapid intensification, fast-moving [[Hurricane Emily (1987)|Hurricane Emily]] makes landfall at Category 1 intensity,<ref name="emily2">{{cite web|author=Harold P. Gerrish|title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Emily|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 10, 2015|page=2|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1987-prelim/emily/prelim02.gif}}</ref> battering the island with a brief burst of destructive winds.<ref name="emily4">{{cite web|author=Harold P. Gerrish|title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Emily|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 10, 2015|page=4|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1987-prelim/emily/prelim04.gif}}</ref> The storm's outer bands spawn "dozens" of waterspouts and tornadoes, some of which cause injuries and property damage.<ref name="list"/><ref name="emily4"/> Sustained winds of {{convert|86|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} with gusts to {{convert|116|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} bring down many trees, cited as between 80% and 90% of all specimens in the territory. Boats, cars, and utilities also suffer.<ref name="emily4"/> Of 2,500 houses impacted by the storm, about 200 receive major roof damage.<ref name="emily4"/><ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Atlantic cools force of Hurricane Emily|date=September 27, 1987|newspaper=The Salina Journal|accessdate=November 10, 2015|url=https://www.newspapers.com/clip/3599636/the_salina_journal/|via=[[Newspapers.com]]}} {{open access}}</ref> All roads on the island are obstructed by toppled trees and utility poles.<ref name="tucker151">Tucker, p. 151</ref> Losses are estimated at $35 million,<ref name="list"/> and over 100 people are treated for minor storm-related injuries.<ref name="rg"/> *November 24, 1988 – Bermuda experiences one-minute sustained winds of {{convert|47|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and gusts to {{convert|78|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} as [[Tropical Storm Keith (1988)|Tropical Storm Keith]] to the north becomes extratropical.<ref name="mwr">{{cite journal|author=Miles B. Lawrence|author2=James M. Gross |date=October 1989|title=Atlantic Hurricane Season of 1988|journal=Monthly Weather Review|publisher=American Meteorological Society|volume=117|issue=10|pages=2248–2259|doi=10.1175/1520-0493(1989)117<2248:AHSO>2.0.CO;2 |bibcode=1989MWRv..117.2248L }}</ref> *August 6, 1989 – The eastern eyewall of Category 2 [[Hurricane Dean (1989)|Hurricane Dean]] crosses the island.<ref name="list"/> Winds sustained at {{convert|81|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} with gusts to {{convert|113|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} are reported on the western end. The storm damages at least 648 buildings, along with dozens of boats and vehicles, and sixteen people are injured to some degree.<ref name="deantcr">{{cite web|author=Max Mayfield|title=Preliminary Report: Hurricane Dean|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 11, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1989-prelim/dean/prelim02.gif}}</ref> Storm-heightened tides flood coastal streets and homes,<ref>{{cite news|title=Hurricane thrashes Bermuda|date=August 7, 1989|newspaper=St. Louis Post-Dispatch|via=LexisNexis}}</ref> while several inches of rain are measured.<ref name="list"/> A parking lot at the airport is totally washed out along with several vehicles.<ref>Tucker, p. 152</ref> [[Naval Air Station Bermuda]] sustains $3.9 million in damage, contributing to a storm total of $8.9 million.<ref name="deantcr"/> *September 7, 1989 – Large waves from distant [[Hurricane Gabrielle (1989)|Hurricane Gabrielle]] erode beaches on the south shore.<ref name="Tucker, p. 153">Tucker, p. 153</ref>
===1990s=== *July 30, 1990 – [[Hurricane Bertha (1990)|Hurricane Bertha]] passes to the northwest, producing wind gusts to {{convert|45|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite news|author=Associated Press|title=Bertha, first hurricane, sputters out|date=July 30, 1990|newspaper=The Daily Union|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=lbREAAAAIBAJ&sjid=DbYMAAAAIBAJ&pg=3350,2459948}}</ref> [[File:Grace 1991-10-28 1601Z.png|right|thumb|[[Hurricane Grace (1991)|Hurricane Grace]] near Bermuda in October 1991|alt=Visible satellite image of Hurricane Grace]]
*October 11, 1990 – [[Hurricane Lili (1990)|Hurricane Lili]] passes to the south, resulting in squally weather.<ref>{{cite news|author=Leanne Waxman|title=Hurricane Lili Lashes North Carolina|date=October 12, 1990|newspaper=The Associated Press|via=LexisNexis}}</ref> *October 20, 1990 – [[Hurricane Nana (1990)|Tropical Storm Nana]] meanders to the south, dropping {{convert|0.33|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain.<ref name="dr">{{cite web|author=David Roth|title=Tropical Cyclone Point Maxima|publisher=Weather Prediction Center|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url=http://www.wpc.ncep.noaa.gov/tropical/rain/tcmaxima.html}}</ref> *September 8, 1991 – [[Hurricane Claudette (1991)|Hurricane Claudette]] recurves to the east, yielding breezy rainshowers.<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard Pasch|title=Hurricane Claudette Preliminary Report Page 3|year=1991|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1991/claudett/prenhc/prelim03.gif}}</ref> *October 29, 1991 – [[Hurricane Grace (1991)|Hurricane Grace]] passes about {{convert|60|mi|km|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} to the south, dropping {{convert|3.21|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain and severely eroding beaches.<ref name="Tucker, p. 153"/><ref name="dr"/> Grace later contributes to the formation of the well-known [[1991 Perfect Storm]].<ref>{{cite web|author=Edward Rappaport|title=Hurricane Grace Preliminary Report Page 3|date=November 13, 1991|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1991-prelim/grace/prelim03.gif}}</ref> *October 22, 1994 – [[Hurricane Chris (1994)|Hurricane Chris]] passes to the southeast, producing {{convert|2.83|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain.<ref>{{cite web|author=Miles Lawrence|title=Hurricane Chris Preliminary Report Page 2|date=September 21, 1994|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url=http://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/storm_wallets/atlantic/atl1994-prelim/chris/prelim01.gif}}</ref> *August 15, 1995 – [[Hurricane Felix (1995)|Hurricane Felix]] passes about {{convert|70|mi|km}} to the south-southwest, generating sustained winds of {{convert|63|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} with gusts to {{convert|81|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|author1=Max Mayfield |author2=Jack Beven |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Hurricane Felix Preliminary Report|date=November 19, 1995|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL071995_Felix}}}}</ref> The slow-moving storm cuts power to about 18,000 electric customers, delays an [[Bermudian independence referendum, 1995|independence referendum]], and causes $2.5 million in damage.<ref name="rg">{{cite news|author=Owain Johnston-Barnes|title=Hurricanes that hit in recent times|date=September 6, 2012|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20120906/NEWS/709069945}}</ref> Rough seas break boats from their moorings and destroy long swaths of the Causeway's safety walls.<ref name="tucker154">Tucker, pp. 154–155</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Bermuda Braced 85mph Hurricane|date=August 16, 1995|newspaper=The Evening Standard|via=LexisNexis}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Wind of change swept away by 100mph gusts|date=August 16, 1995|newspaper=The Harold|via=LexisNexis}}</ref> Two other bridges in St. George's receive damage.<ref name="tucker154"/> *September 10, 1995 – [[Hurricane Luis]] passes to the northwest, accompanied by gusts to {{convert|56|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|author=Miles Lawrence|title=Hurricane Luis Preliminary Report|date=January 8, 1996|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL131995_Luis}}}}</ref> *September 19, 1995 – [[Hurricane Marilyn]] passes to the west, producing tropical storm-force winds with gusts to {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|author=Edward Rappaport|title=Hurricane Marilyn Preliminary Report|date=January 17, 1996|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL151995_Marilyn}}}}</ref> No appreciable damage is reported.<ref>{{cite news|author=Steve Marshall|title=Marilyn whips up surf, heads north|date=September 20, 1995|newspaper=USA Today|via=LexisNexis}}</ref> *October 20, 1996 – [[Hurricane Lili (1996)|Hurricane Lili]] passes to the southeast, buffeting the island with gusty winds.<ref name="bol">{{cite web|author=Keith Archibald Forbes|title=Bermuda's Climate and Weather|publisher=Bermuda Online|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url=http://www.bermuda-online.org/climateweather.htm}}</ref> *September 3, 1998 – [[Hurricane Danielle (1998)|Hurricane Danielle]] passes to the northwest, causing {{convert|39|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} winds with gusts to {{convert|54|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard Pasch|title=Hurricane Danielle Preliminary Report|date=January 19, 1999|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL041998_Danielle}}}}</ref> *September 21, 1999 – [[Hurricane Gert (1999)|Hurricane Gert]] passes to the southeast, brushing the island with gusts to {{convert|74|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at the airport (slightly higher at exposed coastal locations), as well as light rainfall.<ref>{{cite web|author=Miles Lawrence|title=Hurricane Gert Preliminary Report|date=July 22, 2000|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL091999_Gert}}}}</ref> Above-average tides and {{convert|25|to|30|ft|m|abbr=on}} waves leave significant beach erosion and affect an estimated 1,100 buildings,<ref>{{citation|title=Preliminary Report on the Effects of Hurricane Gert on Bermuda, 21st September 1999|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service}}</ref> while 10,000 homes lose power.<ref>{{cite news|author=Reuters News Service|title=Hurricane Gert Expected to Skirt Bermuda|date=September 21, 1999|newspaper=The Deseret News|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=336&dat=19990921&id=pe8jAAAAIBAJ&sjid=N-0DAAAAIBAJ&pg=2559,3350403&hl=en}}</ref>
===2000–2005=== [[File:Pre Karen ET storm.jpg|right|thumb|[[Hurricane Karen (2001)|Subtropical Storm Karen]] near Bermuda in October 2001|alt=Enhanced infrared satellite image of the subtropical storm Karen]] *September 16, 2000 – [[Hurricane Florence (2000)|Hurricane Florence]] passes about {{convert|80|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the northwest, with tropical storm-force winds and light rain.<ref>{{cite web|author=James Franklin|title=Hurricane Florence Preliminary Report|date=November 9, 2000|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url={{NHC TCR
