url|id=AL102000_Florence}}}}</ref> *October 15, 2000 – The precursor disturbance to [[Hurricane Michael (2000)|Hurricane Michael]] drops several inches of rain.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for October 2000|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|date=November 13, 2000|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/data/2000-10.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051025050628/http://www.weather.bm/data/2000-10.html|archivedate=2005-10-25}}</ref> *August 25, 2001 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Dean (2001)|Tropical Storm Dean]] induce inclement weather.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for August 2001|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/data/2001-08.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205194205/http://www.weather.bm/data/2001-08.html|archivedate=2012-02-05}}</ref> *September 10, 2001 – Gusty winds from [[Hurricane Erin (2001)|Hurricane Erin]] to the northeast damage trees and powerlines.<ref>{{cite news|title=Weakening Hurricane Erin spawns strong waves along East Coast|date=September 11, 2001|publisher=CNN|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url=http://archives.cnn.com/2001/WEATHER/09/11/hurricane.erin/index.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070720190608/http://archives.cnn.com/2001/WEATHER/09/11/hurricane.erin/index.html|archivedate=2007-07-20}}</ref> *September 17, 2001 – [[Hurricane Gabrielle (2001)|Hurricane Gabrielle]] passes to the northwest, attended by showers and thunderstorms.<ref name="september01">{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for September 2001|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/data/2001-09.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205194246/http://www.weather.bm/data/2001-09.html|archivedate=2012-02-05}}</ref> *September 23, 2001 – [[Hurricane Humberto (2001)|Hurricane Humberto]] passes to the west, producing {{convert|43|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} wind gusts and {{convert|1.69|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain.<ref>{{cite web|author=James Franklin|title=Hurricane Humberto Preliminary Report|date=October 30, 2001|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL102001_Humberto}}}}</ref> *October 11, 2001 – [[Hurricane Karen (2001)|Subtropical Storm Karen]] strengthens near Bermuda, resulting in damaging wind gusts as high as {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on|sigfig=3}}; a ship at harbour reports a much higher gust, possibly the result of localised [[atmospheric convection|convection]]. The storm system destroys numerous boats and leaves some 23,000 households without power,<ref name="karentcr">{{cite web|author=Stacy Stewart|title=Hurricane Karen Preliminary Report|date=April 17, 2002|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL132001_Karen}}}}</ref> accounting for more than two-thirds of electric customers.<ref name="rg"/> *November 7, 2001 – The combination of [[Hurricane Michelle]]'s extratropical remnants and a developing non-tropical low bring rainy and blustery weather.<ref name="nov2001">{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for November 2001|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=October 9, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/data/2001-11.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051025051504/http://www.weather.bm/data/2001-11.html|archivedate=2005-10-25}}</ref> *November 26 – December 3, 2001 – The tight pressure gradient between distant [[Hurricane Olga]] to the east and high pressure to the northwest generates a prolonged period of winds near or above gale force.<ref name="nov2001"/> As Olga moves slowly and erratically southwestward, the effects of its outer reaches include {{convert|2.2|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain on December 3 and {{convert|15|to|22|ft|m|abbr=on}} swells.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for December 2001|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=September 13, 2017|url=http://www.weather.bm/climatereport/data/2001-12.html}}</ref><ref name="trg">{{cite news|author=Roger Williams Director|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|date=June 2, 2002|title=Bermuda was affected by several Tropical Cyclones during the 2001 season|accessdate=September 13, 2017|url=http://www.theroyalgazette.com/siftology.royalgazette/Article/article.jsp?articleId=7d2620f3003002e&sectionId=49|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070906164449/http://www.theroyalgazette.com/siftology.royalgazette/Article/article.jsp?articleId=7d2620f3003002e&sectionId=49|dead-url=yes|archive-date=September 6, 2007}}</ref> *August 9, 2002 – The remnants of [[Tropical Storm Cristobal (2002)|Tropical Storm Cristobal]] interact with a [[weather front|cold front]] to produce squally conditions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for August 2002|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=October 9, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/data/2002-08.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208145015/http://www.weather.bm/data/2002-08.html|archivedate=2012-02-08}}</ref> *September 7–9, 2002 – [[Hurricane Gustav|Subtropical Storm Gustav]] develops to the southwest, delivering persistent clouds and showers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for September 2002|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=October 9, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/data/2002-09.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205194231/http://www.weather.bm/data/2002-09.html|archivedate=2012-02-05}}</ref> *October 1–2, 2002 – As [[Hurricane Kyle (2002)|Tropical Storm Kyle]] slowly passes to the south, its outer [[rainband|bands]] drop half of Bermuda's monthly precipitation total for October.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for October 2002|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=October 9, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/data/2002-10.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120310050136/http://www.weather.bm/data/2002-10.html|archivedate=2012-03-10}}</ref> *April 18–21, 2003 – [[Tropical Storm Ana (2003)|Subtropical Storm Ana]] develops west of Bermuda before slowly looping around to the south as a fully tropical cyclone. The island experiences gusty winds and heavy showers.<ref>{{cite web|date=May 5, 2003|title=Weather Summary for April 2003|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=October 9, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/data/2003-04.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120208144954/http://www.weather.bm/data/2003-04.html|archivedate=2012-02-08}}</ref> [[File:BDA Fabian damage3.jpg|right|thumb|A road at [[Bermuda International Airport]] washed out by [[Hurricane Fabian]] in September 2003|alt=A crumbled roadway at the water's edge]] *September 5, 2003 – The island enters the eastern eyewall of Category 3 [[Hurricane Fabian]], the most destructive hurricane in the territory since 1926.<ref name="fabiantcr">{{cite web|author1=Richard Pasch |author2=Eric Blake |author3=Daniel Brown |last-author-amp=yes |title=Hurricane Fabian Tropical Cyclone Report|date=November 19, 2003|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=October 9, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL102003_Fabian}}}}</ref> Elevated stations record wind gusts in excess of {{convert|150|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}, while the south shore is subjected to {{convert|20|to|30|ft|m|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} waves and an estimated {{convert|10|ft|m|abbr=on}} [[storm surge]].<ref name="fabiantcr"/> Seawater inundates beachfront structures and compromises the Causeway,<ref name="slideshow">{{cite web|title=Hurricane Fabian slideshow|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=November 3, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/TropicalArchive/fabian/fabian_slideshow.html}}</ref> where four people are swept away in their vehicles. Fabian produces considerable damage to property and vegetation, unroofing some buildings in exposed locations and causing more severe failures in weaker structures.<ref name="fabiantcr"/> The wind damage is possibly exacerbated by several small tornadoes reportedly embedded in the hurricane's eyewall.<ref name="slideshow"/> About 25,000 electric customers lose power,<ref name="rg"/> and total damage exceeds $300 million.<ref name="fabiantcr"/> Fabian is the only tropical cyclone in the [[weather satellite]] era to directly cause fatalities on Bermuda.<ref name="list"/> In response to the hurricane's destruction, the name ''Fabian'' is [[list of retired Atlantic hurricanes|retired]] and replaced with ''Fred'' for 2009.<ref name="WMO">{{cite web|author1=Oficina Nacional de Meteorología |author2=Centro de Información Huracanes |year=2004|title=Reports of hurricanes, tropical storms, tropical disturbances and related flooding during 2003|accessdate=January 20, 2016|url=http://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/tcp/documents/HC26-English.pdf|format=PDF|work=Final Report of the Twenty-Sixth Session|publisher=World Meteorological Organization}}</ref> *September 27, 2003 – [[Hurricane Juan]]'s passage to the east is marked by gusty winds.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for November 2003|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=November 3, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/data/2003-09.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120205194157/http://www.weather.bm/data/2003-09.html|archivedate=2012-02-05}}</ref> *October 8–10, 2004 – [[Subtropical Storm Nicole (2004)|Subtropical Storm Nicole]] and its precursor disturbance overspread the island with heavy rainfall and winds up to {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref name="list"/> The system causes minor power outages.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Sarah Titterton |author2=Eloisa Mayers |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Nicole drowns out the music|date=October 11, 2004|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=November 3, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20041011/NEWS/310119988}}</ref> *July 26, 2005 – [[Tropical Storm Franklin (2005)|Tropical Storm Franklin]] far to the west generates {{convert|37|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} wind gusts.<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard D. Knabb|title=Tropical Storm Franklin Tropical Cyclone Report|date=March 17, 2006|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 3, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL062005_Franklin}}}}</ref> *August 4, 2005 – [[Tropical Storm Harvey (2005)|Tropical Storm Harvey]] passes about {{convert|30|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the south, producing tropical storm-force winds and {{convert|5.02|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain. The heavy rainfall creates some transient street flooding.<ref>{{cite web|author=Richard D. Knabb|title=Tropical Storm Harvey Tropical Cyclone Report|date=March 17, 2006|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 3, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL082005_Harvey}}}}</ref> *September 8, 2005 – [[Hurricane Nate (2005)|Hurricane Nate]] passes to the south, producing rainshowers and wind gusts to {{convert|58|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stacy R. Stewart|date=November 29, 2005|title=Hurricane Nate Tropical Cyclone Report|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 4, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL152005_Nate}}}}</ref> *October 25, 2005 – Thunderstorms and gusty winds are observed as [[Hurricane Wilma]] passes far to the northwest.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for October 2005|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=November 4, 2015|url=http://www.weather.bm/data/2005-10.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061126033009/http://www.weather.bm/data/2005-10.html|archivedate=2006-11-26}}</ref>
===2006–2010=== *September 11, 2006 – Category 1 [[Hurricane Florence (2006)|Hurricane Florence]] passes about {{convert|60|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the northwest and bears damaging winds, gusting to {{convert|90|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at the airport.<ref>{{cite web|author=Jack Beven|title=Hurricane Florence Tropical Cyclone Report|date=January 4, 2007|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 5, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL072006_Florence}}}}</ref> The winds bring down trees and powerlines, leaving 25,000 households without power, and damage about ten buildings.<ref name="list"/><ref>{{cite news|author=Elizabeth Roberts|title=Bermuda Dodges Florence With No Injuries|date=September 12, 2006|newspaper=Associated Press|accessdate=November 5, 2015|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/09/12/AR2006091200682.html}}</ref> A small tornado is reported in [[Southampton Parish, Bermuda|Southmapton Parish]] within one of the hurricane's outer bands. Overall damage amounts to $200,000.<ref name="list"/> *November 2–3, 2007 – As [[Hurricane Noel]] far to the west transitions into a large extratropical cyclone, Bermuda experiences rough seas and gale-force winds.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for November 2007 |publisher=Bermuda Weather Service |accessdate=November 5, 2015 |url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216052441/http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |archivedate=December 16, 2009 |df= }}</ref> *July 14, 2008 – [[Hurricane Bertha (2008)|Tropical Storm Bertha]] passes about {{convert|40|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the east; tropical storm-force winds, gusting as fast as {{convert|91|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at elevated stations, damage tree limbs and powerlines. Bertha drops about {{convert|5|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain, which leads to minor street flooding.<ref name="list"/> *September 27–28, 2008 – [[Hurricane Kyle (2008)|Tropical Storm Kyle]] to the west intensifies into a hurricane, brushing the island with gusty winds and heavy showers.<ref name="list"/> *August 21, 2009 – [[Hurricane Bill (2009)|Hurricane Bill]] passes to the west, causing squally conditions and high swells that reach {{convert|35|ft|m|abbr=on}} just outside the reefs. The storm unmoors several boats, erodes beaches, and briefly cuts power to a few thousand customers.<ref name="list"/><ref>{{cite news|author=Amanda Dale |title=WITH VIDEO: Normalcy returns after Bill|date=August 24, 2009|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=November 5, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20090824/NEWS/308249980}}</ref> [[File:Large waves in Bermuda from Hurricane Igor.jpg|right|thumb|Rough seas from [[Hurricane Igor]] in September 2010|alt=Sea spray fills the air amid high waves breaking on rocky coastline]]
*August 7–8, 2010 – [[Tropical Storm Colin (2010)|Tropical Storm Colin]] approaches from the south with building seas, but dissipates before reaching the island. The dissipating system produces squally conditions.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for August 2010 |publisher=Bermuda Weather Service |date=September 1, 2010 |accessdate=November 8, 2015 |url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216052441/http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |archivedate=December 16, 2009 |df= }}</ref> *September 4, 2010 – The island experiences inclement weather from the remnants of [[Tropical Storm Fiona]].<ref name="list"/> *September 19–20, 2010 – As Category 1 [[Hurricane Igor]] passes about {{convert|60|mi|km|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} to the west, the airport records ten-minute sustained winds of {{convert|68|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} with gusts to {{convert|93|mph|km/h|abbr=on}}; gusts over {{convert|115|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} are measured at elevated stations. Igor also produces {{convert|3.19|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain and a minor storm surge.<ref name="igortcr">{{cite web|author1=Richard J. Pasch |author2=Todd B. Kimberlain |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Hurricane Igor Tropical Cyclone Report|date=February 15, 2011|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 8, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL112010_Igor}}}}</ref> Igor causes less destruction than feared, leading to only minor structural damage and coastal flooding, but still cuts power to nearly 29,000 households.<ref name="AFP1">{{cite news|author=James Whittaker |agency=Agence France-Presse |date=September 20, 2010 |accessdate=November 8, 2015 |title=Bermuda emerges unscathed from Hurricane Igor |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i_gL6c04MxhoEcrfqrHLJ5NMUzRQ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5stC3aNsB?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5i_gL6c04MxhoEcrfqrHLJ5NMUzRQ |archivedate=September 20, 2010 |df= }}</ref> The storm causes an estimated $500,000 in damage.<ref name="igortcr"/> *October 29, 2010 – Category 1 [[Hurricane Shary]], an unusually small storm, passes {{convert|80|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the southeast with no major effects.<ref name="list"/>
===2011–2015=== *August 15, 2011 – [[Tropical Storm Gert (2011)|Tropical Storm Gert]] passes about {{convert|90|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the east, bringing light rain and breezy winds.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for August 2011 |publisher=Bermuda Weather Service |date=September 1, 2011 |accessdate=November 8, 2015 |url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216052441/http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |archivedate=December 16, 2009 |df= }}</ref> *August 28, 2011 – A weakening [[Tropical Storm Jose (2011)|Tropical Storm Jose]] passes about {{convert|60|mi|km|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} to the west with bands of showers and strong wind gusts.<ref name="list"/> *September 15, 2011 – A brief period of squally weather, marked by wind gusts to {{convert|69|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and light rainfall accumulations, accompanies the passage of [[Hurricane Maria (2011)|Hurricane Maria]] to the west.<ref name="list"/> *October 1, 2011 – [[Hurricane Ophelia (2011)|Major Hurricane Ophelia]] passes to the east with little fanfare. High surf and some breezy showers are reported.<ref name="list"/> *November 11, 2011 – [[Subtropical Storm Sean|Tropical Storm Sean]] passes about {{convert|80|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the north, producing a short period of tropical storm-force winds.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lixion A. Avila|title=Tropical Storm Sean Tropical Cyclone Report|date=January 12, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 9, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL192011_Sean}}}}</ref> The storm impairs several boats around the island.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jonathan Bell|title=Storm warning remains in effect this morning|date=November 12, 2011|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=November 9, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20111112/NEWS/711129982}}</ref> *June 15–17, 2012 – A non-tropical low pressure area that would later become [[Hurricane Chris (2012)|Hurricane Chris]] drops moderate to heavy rainfall for several days, with a total of {{convert|2.59|in|mm|abbr=on}} on June 15 breaking the daily rainfall record.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for June 2012 |publisher=Bermuda Weather Service |date=July 2, 2012 |accessdate=November 9, 2015 |url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216052441/http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |archivedate=December 16, 2009 |df= }}</ref> Several streets in poor-drainage areas are flooded, some to a depth of {{convert|4|ft|m|abbr=on}}.<ref>{{cite news|author=Tim Smith|title=Flooding and traffic gridlock as downpours hit Island|date=June 16, 2012|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=November 9, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20120616/NEWS/706169999}}</ref> On June 17, as the system continues to develop, a small but intense gale center moves over the island, marked by gusts of {{convert|64|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at the airport.<ref>{{cite web|author=Stacy R. Stewart|title=Hurricane Chris Tropical Cyclone Report|date=January 22, 2012|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 9, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL032012_Chris}}}}</ref> *September 8–10, 2012 – Slow-moving [[Hurricane Leslie (2012)|Tropical Storm Leslie]] to the east drops {{convert|5.17|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain, most of which falls on September 9, the island's wettest day in several years;<ref name="list"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for September 2012 |publisher=Bermuda Weather Service |date=September 28, 2012 |accessdate=November 9, 2015 |url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216052441/http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |archivedate=December 16, 2009 |df= }}</ref> only minor flooding is reported. Gusty winds cause limited power outages, chiefly from powerline contact with overhanging vegetation.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jonathan Bell|title=Most storm power outages caused by vegetation — Belco|date=September 11, 2012|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=November 9, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20120911/NEWS/709119922}}</ref> *October 16–17, 2012 – [[Hurricane Rafael]] passes to the east, delivering gusty winds and moderate rainfall.<ref name="list"/> About 1,000 electric customers lose power for a short time.<ref>{{cite news|title=Hurricane Rafael spares Bermuda|date=October 17, 2012|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=November 9, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20121017/NEWS/710179941}}</ref> *October 27–29, 2012 – Outer bands from the expansive [[Hurricane Sandy]] to the west affect Bermuda. In addition to wind gusts as high as {{convert|64|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and light rainfall, the storm's fringes produce a weak tornado in [[Somerset Village, Bermuda|Somerset Village]] that does minor structural damage.<ref name="list"/> *September 10–11, 2013 – [[2013 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Gabrielle|Tropical Storm Gabrielle]] passes about {{convert|25|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the west, causing various minor damage and light power outages.<ref>{{cite web|author=Lixion A. Avila|title=Tropical Storm Gabrielle Tropical Cyclone Report|date=October 25, 2013|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 9, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL072013_Gabrielle}}}}</ref> A few trees and tree limbs are blown down.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ceola Wilson|title=Island’s attention turns to Humberto|date=September 12, 2013|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=November 9, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20130912/NEWS/130919887}}</ref> *August 27–28, 2014 – [[Hurricane Cristobal (2014)|Hurricane Cristobal]] passes far to the northwest, with its effects limited to gusty winds and heightened surf.<ref name="list"/> [[File:Fay storm damage Bermuda.jpg|right|thumb|A small yacht wrecked by [[Hurricane Fay (2014)|Hurricane Fay]] in October 2014|alt=A small, upended yacht resting on a rock]]
*October 12, 2014 – Category 1 [[Hurricane Fay (2014)|Hurricane Fay]] makes landfall in Bermuda, causing an unexpectedly great degree of damage. Wind gusts over {{convert|100|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} clog roadways with downed trees and utility poles, and leave most electric customers without power. Along the coast, Fay damages or destroys numerous boats and inundates streets.<ref name="faytcr">{{cite web|author=Todd B. Kimberlain|title=Hurricane Fay Tropical Cyclone Report|date=April 24, 2015|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 9, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL072014_Fay}}}}</ref> The terminal building at the airport suffers extensive flooding after the powerful winds compromise its roof and sprinkler system.<ref>{{cite news|author1=Jonathan Bell |author2=Simon Jones |lastauthoramp=yes|title=Airport flooding causes ‘rolling delays’|date=October 12, 2014|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=November 9, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20141012/NEWS/141019930}}</ref> Insured losses from Fay likely total "tens of millions of dollars."<ref name="bwsreport">{{cite report|author=Bermuda Weather Service|title=Review of the Past Hurricane Season|date=April 2015|publisher=World Meteorological Organization RA IV Hurricane Committee|accessdate=October 31, 2015|url=https://www.wmo.int/pages/prog/www/tcp/documents/HC-37D0c424bermuda.doc}}</ref> *October 17–18, 2014 – While cleanup and repairs from Fay are still underway, Category 2 [[Hurricane Gonzalo]] makes landfall on the southwestern coast, severely compounding the damage.<ref name="gonzalotcr">{{cite web|author=Daniel P. Brown|title=Hurricane Gonzalo Tropical Cyclone Report|date=March 4, 2015|publisher=National Hurricane Center|accessdate=November 10, 2015|url={{NHC TCR url|id=AL082014_Gonzalo}}}}</ref> The territory experiences up to 12 hours of hurricane-force winds, peaking at {{convert|144|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at [[St. David's Island, Bermuda]]; consequently, widespread roof and structural damage is reported.<ref name="bwsreport"/> At the height of the storm, about 31,000 out of 36,000 electricity customers are without power, including 1,500 residual outages from Fay.<ref>{{cite news|title=Belco restoration: 26,775 without power at 11.30am|date=October 18, 2014|work=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=October 18, 2014|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20141018/NEWS/141019704}}</ref> The hurricane destroys many boats and inflicts minor damage on Causeway, limiting traffic to one lane for several days.<ref name="bwsreport"/> Tees and utility poles once again leave "barely a road passable" across the island,<ref>{{cite news|title=Roads blocked and serious damage Island-wide|date=October 18, 2014|work=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=November 10, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20141018/NEWS/141019705}}</ref> and the Bermuda Weather Service building endures wind and water damage. The most significant storm to affect Bermuda since Fabian in 2003, Gonzalo is generally less destructive, and causes no deaths or major injuries.<ref name="bwsreport"/> Insured losses are estimated at between $200 and $400 million.<ref name="gonzalotcr"/> *October 4–5, 2015 – Category 1 [[Hurricane Joaquin]] passes about {{convert|70|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the west-northwest, producing several inches of rain and strong winds, gusting as high as {{convert|115|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} at exposed and elevated locations.<ref>{{cite web|author=Bermuda Weather Service|date=October 6, 2015|work=Bermuda Weather Service official Facebook page|url=https://www.facebook.com/BermudaWeatherService/photos/a.178317008997868.1073741829.175763602586542/510447839118115/?type=3&permPage=1|title=Facebook post on Hurricane Joaquin on Tuesday, October 6, 2015|accessdate=October 6, 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for October 2015 |publisher=Bermuda Weather Service |date=November 2, 2015 |accessdate=November 10, 2015 |url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091216052441/http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |archivedate=December 16, 2009 |df= }}</ref> A structure at the [[Bermuda Maritime Museum]] is partially unroofed,<ref>{{cite news|author=Jonathon Bell|title=Fresh roof damage at Commissioner’s Point|date=October 5, 2015|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20151005/NEWS/151009832}}</ref> and about 15,000 households lose electricity,<ref>{{cite news|author=Jonathan Bell|title=West End bears the brunt of Joaquin|date=October 6, 2015|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=October 6, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20151006/NEWS/151009800}}</ref> but damage is generally inconsequential.<ref>{{cite news|author=Jonathon Bell|title=BF&M: little property damage|date=October 5, 2015|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=October 5, 2015|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20151005/NEWS/151009833}}</ref>
===2016–present=== *January 8, 2016 – The extratropical cyclone that would later become [[Hurricane Alex (2016)|Hurricane Alex]] generates rough seas and {{convert|60|mph|km/h|abbr=on|sigfig=1}} wind gusts. Along with sporadic power outages, air travel and ferry services are interrupted.<ref name="TRG1">{{cite news|author=Jonathan Bell|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|date=January 8, 2016|accessdate=January 15, 2016|title=Windy weather affects flights and power|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/article/20160108/NEWS/160109802}}</ref> *September 24, 2016 – [[Tropical Storm Karl (2016)|Tropical Storm Karl]] passes about {{convert|50|mi|km|abbr=on}} to the southeast, producing {{convert|3.89|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain and tropical storm-force winds.<ref>{{cite web |title=Weather Summary for September 2016 |publisher=Bermuda Weather Service |date=September 29, 2016 |accessdate=September 29, 2016 |url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620155043/http://www.weather.bm/climatereport/climateReport.asp |archive-date=2012-06-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> The storm cuts power to about 800 electric customers, but overall damage is minor.<ref>{{cite news|author=Lisa Simpson|title=TS Karl skirts island: outages, storm surge|date=September 24, 2016|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=September 29, 2016|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/storm/article/20160924/ts-karl-skirts-island-outages-storm-surge}}</ref> *October 13, 2016 – The eye of Category 3 [[Hurricane Nicole (2016)|Hurricane Nicole]] passes over the islands, though the exact center remains just offshore. Gusts as high as {{convert|136|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} blow down trees and power lines, which cuts power to nearly 90% of the territory's electric customers.<ref name="bmnicole">{{cite web |title=BWS Daily Climatology Written Summary |date=October 26, 2016 |url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp |accessdate=October 26, 2016 |publisher=Bermuda Weather Service |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620155043/http://www.weather.bm/climatereport/climateReport.asp |archive-date=2012-06-20 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Photos: The Aftermath Of Hurricane Nicole|date=October 13, 2016|newspaper=Bernews|accessdate=October 13, 2016|url=http://bernews.com/2016/10/photos-aftermath-hurricane-nicole}}</ref> Dozens of boats are damaged or destroyed, and entire fields of crops are lost, although property damage is less severe than anticipated.<ref>{{cite news|author=Sarah Lagan|title=Dozens of boats damaged or sunk|date=October 18, 2016|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=October 24, 2016|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/news/article/20161018/dozens-of-boats-damaged-or-sunk}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=Simon Jones|title=Farmers count the cost of hurricane damage|date=October 22, 2016|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=October 24, 2016|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/storm/article/20161022/farmers-count-cost-of-hurricane-damage}}</ref><ref name="live">{{cite news|title=Nicole live: storm moves on, Causeway shut|date=October 13, 2016|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=October 12, 2016|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/storm/article/20161013/nicole-live-storm-moves-on-causeway-shut}}</ref> The hurricane drops {{convert|6.77|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain, becoming one of the wettest recorded storms to impact Bermuda.<ref name="bmnicole"/> *August 3–4, 2017 – Showers and thunderstorms accompany the extratropical remnants of [[2017 Atlantic hurricane season#Tropical Storm Emily|Tropical Storm Emily]] as they sweep over the islands.<ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for August 2017|date=September 1, 2017|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=September 13, 2017|url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620155043/http://www.weather.bm/climatereport/climateReport.asp|archive-date=2012-06-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *September 18–19, 2017 – The outer bands of slow-moving [[Hurricane Jose (2017)|Hurricane Jose]] bring gusts as high as {{convert|46|mph|km/h|abbr=on}} and nearly {{convert|2.5|in|mm|abbr=on}} of rain, as well as a prolonged period of large swells.<ref>{{cite news|title=Jose brings strong winds and risk of thunder|date=September 18, 2017|newspaper=The Royal Gazette|accessdate=September 19, 2017|url=http://www.royalgazette.com/news/article/20170918/jose-brings-strong-winds-and-risk-of-thunder}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for September 2017|date=September 30, 2017|url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp|accessdate=September 19, 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620155043/http://www.weather.bm/climatereport/climateReport.asp|archive-date=2012-06-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *July 9, 2018 – Moderate showers signal the arrival of [[atmospheric instability]] and moisture from [[2018 Atlantic hurricane season#Hurricane Chris|Tropical Storm Chris]] to the southwest.<ref name="july18">{{cite web|title=Weather Summary for July 2018|date=July 11, 2018|publisher=Bermuda Weather Service|accessdate=July 11, 2018|url=http://www.weather.bm/climate.asp|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120620155043/http://www.weather.bm/climatereport/climateReport.asp|archive-date=2012-06-20|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> *July 13, 2018 – The extratropical remnants of [[Hurricane Beryl]], passing between Bermuda and the United States, give rise to light rain and gusty winds.<ref name="july18"/> On the next day, the disturbance regenerates into a subtropical cyclone while centered {{convert|290|mi|km|abbr=on}} north of the islands.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/archive/2018/al02/al022018.public.016.shtml?|title=Subtropical Storm Beryl Special Advisory Number 16|author=Jack Beven|publisher=National Hurricane Center|date=July 14, 2018|accessdate=July 15, 2018}}</ref>
==Monthly statistics and landfalls== <!-- TABLE LAST UPDATED AFTER BERYL --> {{Col-begin}} {{Col-2}} {{bar graph|float=center | title = Number of recorded storms affecting Bermuda | data_max = 100 | label_type = Month | data_type = Number of storms | label1 = January | data1 = 1 | label2 = February | data2 = 0 | label3 = March | data3 = 0 | label4 = April | data4 = 1 | label5 = May | data5 = 0 | label6 = June | data6 = 3 | label7 = July | data7 = 11 | label8 = August | data8 = 30 | label9 = September | data9 = 70 | label10 = October | data10 = 53 | label11 = November | data11 = 10 | label12 = December | data12 = 0 | label13 = Unspecified | data13 = 7 }} {{Col-2}} {| class="wikitable sortable plainrowheaders" |+ Recorded tropical cyclone landfalls in Bermuda |- ! scope="row" | [[Tropical Storm Brenda (1964)|Brenda]] | style="text-align:center;"| {{sort|0808|August 8}} | style="text-align:center;"| {{sort|1964|1964}} |bgcolor=#{{storm colour|storm}} align="center"|{{sort|2|Tropical Storm}} |align="right"| {{sort|050|50 mph (85 km/h)}} |- ! page.title: List of Lepidoptera that feed on Achillea

revision.comment: Lower case for species common names as described at [[MOS:LIFE]] - also some copy editing using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of Lepidoptera that feed on ''Achillea''}} '''''[[Achillea]]''''' (yarrow) species are used as food plants by the [[caterpillar]]s of a number of [[Lepidoptera]] species, primarily moths:
;[[phagy|Monophagous]] species that feed exclusively on ''Achillea'':
*''[[Bucculatrix]]'' leaf miners: :*''[[Bucculatrix albiguttella|B. albiguttella]]'' - feeds on [[yarrow]] :*''[[Bucculatrix capreella|B. capreella]]'' - feeds on yarrow :*''[[Bucculatrix clavenae|B. clavenae]]'' - feeds on yarrow :*''[[Bucculatrix cristatella|B. cristatella]]'' - feeds on yarrow *''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearers: :*''[[Coleophora argentula|C. argentula]]'' - feeds on yarrow :*''[[Coleophora millefolii|C. millefolii]]'' - feeds on yarrow
;[[phagy|Polyphagous]] species that feed on ''Achillea'' among other plants
*[[Bordered pug]] (''Eupithecia succenturiata'') *''[[Bucculatrix jugicola]]'' *''[[Coleophora]]'' case-bearers: :*''[[Coleophora gardesanella|C. gardesanella]]'' :*''[[Coleophora trochilella|C. trochilella]]'' :*''[[Coleophora vibicigerella|C. vibicigerella]]'' *[[Common pug]] (''Eupithecia vulgata'') *[[Grey pug]] (''Eupithecia subfuscata'') *[[Lime-speck pug]] (''Eupithecia centaureata'') *[[Tawny speckled pug]] (''Eupithecia icterata'') *[[V-pug]] (''Chloroclystis v-ata'') *[[Wormwood pug]] (''Eupithecia absinthiata'')
==External links== *[http://www.nhm.ac.uk/our-science/data/hostplants/search/list.dsml?searchPageURL=index.dsml&PGenus=Achillea&sort=Taxon "Search Results Hostplant Genus: ''Achillea''"] at ''HOSTS - a Database of the World's Lepidopteran Hostplants'' of the Natural History Museum, London. Retrieved 7 October 2017.
[[Category:Lists of Lepidoptera by food|Achillea]] [[Category:Achillea|Lepidopter]]

page.title: List of Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Norfolk

revision.text:
{{about|SSSIs in Norfolk|other counties|List of SSSIs by Area of Search}} [[File:Breydon Water Autumn Sunset. - geograph.org.uk - 467120.jpg|thumb|350px|Sunset on [[Breydon Water]]|alt=[Breydon Water]] [[Norfolk]] is a county in [[East Anglia]]. It has an area of {{convert|2,074|sqmi|sqkm|abbr=off}}{{cite encyclopedia|url=https://www.britannica.com/place/Norfolk-county-England|title=Norfolk|date=5 September 2018|encyclopedia=Encyclopedia Britannica|accessdate=15 October 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20180710051427/https://www.britannica.com/place/Norfolk-county-England|archivedate=10 July 2018|deadurl=no|df=}} and a population as of mid-2017 of 898,400.{{cite web|url=http://www.norfolkinsight.org.uk/population|title=Population of Norfolk|publisher=Norfolk Insight|accessdate=15 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180902231435/http://norfolkinsight.org.uk/population|archive-date=2 September 2018|dead-url=no|df=}} The top level of local government is [[Norfolk County Council]] with seven second tier councils: [[Breckland District Council]], [[Broadland District Council]], [[Great Yarmouth Borough Council]], [[King's Lynn and West Norfolk Borough Council]], [[North Norfolk District Council]], [[Norwich City Council]] and [[South Norfolk District Council]].{{cite web|url=https://www.norfolk.gov.uk/what-we-do-and-how-we-work/your-local-councils-mps-and-meps/local-councils|title=Local councils|publisher=Norfolk County Council|accessdate=15 October 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170317070204/https://www.norfolk.gov.uk/what-we-do-and-how-we-work/your-local-councils-mps-and-meps/local-councils|archive-date=17 March 2017|dead-url=no|df=}} The county is bounded by [[Cambridgeshire]], [[Suffolk]], [[Lincolnshire]] and the [[North Sea]]. In England, [[Sites of Special Scientific Interest]] (SSSIs) are designated by [[Natural England]], a [[non-departmental public body]] which is responsible for protecting England's natural environment. Designation as an SSSI gives legal protection to the most important wildlife and geological sites.{{cite web |url=https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sites-of-special-scientific-interest-designation |publisher=Natural England |title=Sites of Special Scientific Interest: Designation |accessdate=19 April 2016 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160306231551/https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/sites-of-special-scientific-interest-designation |archivedate=6 March 2016 |df=}} As of November 2018 there are one hundred and sixty-three SSSIs in Norfolk,{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteList.aspx?siteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&DesignationType=SSSI|title=Designated Sites View: Norfolk|publisher=Natural England |accessdate=21 November 2018}} out of which one hundred and twenty-three are biological, twenty-five geological and fifteen are both biological and geological. Sixty-one sites are [[Special Areas of Conservation]], forty-four are [[Special Protection Area]]s, thirty-two are [[Ramsar site]]s, forty are [[Geological Conservation Review]] sites, thirty-five are [[Nature Conservation Review]] sites, eighteen are [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|National Nature Reserve]]s, ten are [[Local Nature Reserve]]s, twenty-eight are in [[Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty]], one is on the [[Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of Special Historic Interest in England|Register of Historic Parks and Gardens]] and three contain [[Scheduled Monument]]s. Twenty-two sites are managed by the [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust]], one by the [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust]], three by the [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]], one by the [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] and one by the [[Wildfowl & Wetlands Trust]]. {{col-begin}} {{col-2}} ===Interest=== *'''B''' = site of biological interest *'''G''' = site of geological interest ===Public access=== *'''FP''' = access to footpaths through the site only *'''NO''' = no public access to site *'''PL''' = public access at limited times *'''PP''' = public access to part of site *'''YES''' = public access to all or most of the site {{col-2}} ===Other classifications=== *'''AONB''' = [[Area of Outstanding Natural Beauty]] *'''GCR''' = [[Geological Conservation Review]] *'''LNR''' = [[Local Nature Reserve]] *'''NCR''' = [[Nature Conservation Review|Nature Conservation Review site]] *'''NNR''' = [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|National Nature Reserve]] *'''NT''' = [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|National Trust]] *'''NWT''' = [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust]] *'''Ramsar''' = [[Ramsar site]], an internationally important wetland site *'''RHPG'''= [[Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of Special Historic Interest in England]] *'''RSPB''' = [[Royal Society for the Protection of Birds]] *'''SAC''' = [[Special Area of Conservation]] *'''SM''' = [[Scheduled Monument]] *'''SPA''' = [[Special Protection Area]] under the [[European Union]] [[Birds Directive|Directive on the Conservation of Wild Birds]] *'''SWT''' = [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust]] *'''WWT''' = [[Wildfowl & Wetlands Trust]] {{col-end}} {{kml}} ==Sites== {{Compact ToC|side=yes|j=|q=|v=|x=|z=}} {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders sortable" ! scope="col" | Site name ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Photograph ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|B|Site of biological interest}} ! scope="col" |{{tooltip|G|Site of geological interest}} ! scope="col" | Area{{efn|name=details|The area and grid reference are taken from the "Details" page for each site on the Natural England database.}} ! scope="col" | Public access ! scope="col" | Location{{efn|name=details}} ! scope="col" | Other classifications ! scope="col" class="unsortable" | Map{{efn|The maps are provided by Natural England on the ''Magic Map'' website.}} !
