Breeding birds include the [[great crested grebe]], [[water rail]], [[grasshopper warbler]] and [[reed warbler]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000463.pdf |title=Alderfen Broad citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 6 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Alderford Common]] | [[File:Alderford Common 5.jpg|100px|alt=Alderford Common ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 17.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000483&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Alderford Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.720|1.149 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Alderford Common}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 128 183}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000483}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000483.pdf Citation] |The common has a thin layer of glacial sands and gravels over chalk. Habitats include bracken heath, scrub, woodland and ponds, together with species rich grassland in former chalk quarries. An old lime kiln is used by bats and a wide variety of birds breed on the site.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000483.pdf |title=Alderford Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 14 October 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Ant Broads and Marshes]] | [[File:Barton Broad - geograph.org.uk - 231668.jpg|100px|alt=Ant Broads and Marshes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 745.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000501&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Ant Broads and Marshes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Great Yarmouth]]
{{coord|52.739|1.502 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Ant Broads and Marshes }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 365 215}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, p. 307 [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006002&SiteName=broads&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Ant Broads and Marshes | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 25 May 2018}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1084832&SiteName=how+hill&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: How Hill | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 5 June 2018}} [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]],{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/barton-broad |title= Barton Broad |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=21 May 2018}} [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1000501}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000501.pdf Citation] |This site in the valley of the [[River Ant]] is described by [[Natural England]] as "finest example of unpolluted valley fen in Western Europe". It has a network of dykes which support a diverse variety of aquatic plants, and its fenland invertebrate fauna is of national importance.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000501.pdf |title=Ant Broads and Marshes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 6 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Aslacton Parish Land]] | [[File:Aslacton Parish Land 3.jpg|100px|alt=Aslacton Parish Land]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 4.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000311&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Aslacton Parish Land |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.481|1.174 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Aslacton Parish Land }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 156 917}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000311}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000311.pdf Citation] |This site has wet and dry unimproved meadows with a rich flora. Uncommon species include [[marsh arrowgrass]], [[yellow rattle]], [[fragrant orchid]], [[common butterwort]] and [[Ophioglossum vulgatum|adder's tongue]]. [[Snipe]] often breed there.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000311.pdf |title=Aslacton Parish Land citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 29 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|B}}[[Badley Moor ]] | [[File:Badley Moor 6.jpg|100px|alt=Badley Moor]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 18.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000602&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Badley Moor |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Dereham]]
{{coord|52.666|0.974 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Badley Moor }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 012 117}} |[[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0012892&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Norfolk Valley Fens | series=Special Areas of Conservation|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1000602}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000602.pdf Citation] |This area of spring fed fen and grassland in the valley of the [[River Tud]] has [[tufa]] hummocks formed by the deposit of [[calcium carbonate]]. It has an exceptionally rich fen community with a carpet of moss on wet slopes with many unusual plants. There are overgrown dykes with flora including [[Berula erecta|narrow-leaved water-parsnip]] and [[Oenanthe fistulosa|water dropwort]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000602.pdf |title=Badley Moor, Dereham citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 3 September 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Barnham Cross Common]] | [[File:Barnham Cross Common, Thetford - geograph.org.uk - 267796.jpg|100px|alt=Barnhamcross Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 69.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000547&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Barnhamcross Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Thetford]]
{{coord|52.398|0.740 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Barnhamcross Common}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 865 813}} |[[Local Nature Reserve|LNR]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008760&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Barnham Cross Common |series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England |accessdate= 21 May 2018}} [[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, p. 136 [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0019865&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Breckland | series=Special Areas of Conservation|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 25 May 2018}} [[Special Protection Area|SPA]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK9009201&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Breckland | series=Special Protection Areass|publisher=Natural England|accessdate =25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1000547}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000547.pdf Citation] |This grassland and heath common has diverse habitats and a rich flora, including several nationally rare plants. There are nearly a hundred species of birds, including sixty which breed on the site, and a wide range of invertebrates.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000547.pdf |title=Barnhamcross Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 6 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bawsey SSSI|Bawsey]] | [[File:Bawsey SSSI 4.jpg|100px|alt=Bawsey]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 2.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005458&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Bawsey |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord|52.746|0.487 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bawsey}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 680 194}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2296 |title= Bawsey (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1005458}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005458.pdf Citation] |This site has [[Quaternary]] [[till]], unsorted glacial sediments, with a depth of up to five metres. It is separated from the main East Anglian till sheet, and it is the type site for the Bawsey Calcareous Till.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005458.pdf |title=Bawsey citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 31 May 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Beeston Cliffs]] | [[File:Chalk below Beeston Bump (geograph 5555802).jpg|100px|alt=Beeston Cliffs]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 10.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001344&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Beeston Cliffs |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=15 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Sheringham]]
{{coord|52.943|1.227 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Beeston Cliffs}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 169 433}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=610 |title= Beeston (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1001344}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001344.pdf Citation] |This is the [[Type locality (geology)|type site]] for the [[Beestonian stage]] of the [[Early Pleistocene]], between around 1.8 and 0.8 million years ago. It has both marine and freshwater deposits. There is a nationally rare plant, [[Orobanche purpurea|purple broomrape]], in [[calcareous]] grassland on the clifftop.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001344.pdf |title=Beeston Cliffs citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 24 October 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.stratigraphy.org/upload/QuaternaryChart1.JPG|title=Global chronostratigraphical correlation table for the last 2.7 million years|publisher=International Commission on Stratigraphy|accessdate =24 October 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Beetley and Hoe Meadows]] | [[File:Cows graze Hoe Rough - geograph.org.uk - 390936.jpg|100px|Beetley and Hoe Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 11.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002179&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Beetley and Hoe Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Dereham]]
{{coord|52.715|0.930 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Beetley and Hoe Meadows }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 980 171}} |[[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]]{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/hoe-rough |title= Hoe Rough|publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=21 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1002179}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002179.pdf Citation] |This site is described by [[Natural England]] as "one of the finest remaining areas of wet unimproved grassland in Norfolk". It is traditionally managed by summer grazing, with plants such as [[glaucous Sedge]] and [[bog pimpernel]] in marshy parts and [[blunt-flowered rush]] and [[carnation sedge]] in permanently wet areas.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002179.pdf |title=Beetley and Hoe Meadows citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 6 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bilsey Hill]] | [[File:Bilsey Hill 3.jpg|100px|alt=Bilsey Hill]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 3.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005460&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Bilsey Hill |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Holt, Norfolk|Holt]]
{{coord|52.934|1.009 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bilsey Hill }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 023 416}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2297 |title= Bilsey Hill (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1005460}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005460.pdf Citation] |This {{convert|20|m|yd|abbr=off|adj=on}} deep [[Pleistocene]] exposure exhibits a sequence of glacial [[till]], sands and gravels associated with the melt phase of the ice sheet.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005460.pdf |title=Bilsey Hill citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 20 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Blackborough End Pit ]] | [[File:Blackborough End Pit 2.jpg|100px|alt=Blackborough End Pit ]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 13.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001394&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Blackborough End Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord| 52.702|0.469|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Blackborough End Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 669 145}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1218|title= Blackborough End (Berriasian, Valanginian, Hauterivian, Barremian) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1001394}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001394.pdf Citation] |This site is important as a demonstration of erosion during the [[Lower Cretaceous]]. The [[Carstone Formation]], which dates to the [[Albian]] around 110 million years ago, rests [[Unconformity|unconformably]] on the [[Leziate Member|Leziate Beds]], which date to the [[Valanginian]], over 130 million years ago, and the normally intervening [[Dersingham Formation|Dersingham Beds]] are missing.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001394.pdf |title=Blackborough End Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 4 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Blo' Norton and Thelnetham Fens]] | [[File:Thelnetham Fen 6.jpg|100px|alt=Thelnetham Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 21.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000633&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Blo' Norton and Thelnetham Fens |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Diss]]
{{coord|52.370|0.961 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Blo' Norton and Thelnetham Fens }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 017 788}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 214–215 [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]],{{cite web |url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0012882&SiteName=waveney&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Waveney & Little Ouse Valley Fens |series=Special Areas of Conservation |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=10 May 2017}} |{{Nature on the map|1000633}}{{efn|name=suffolk|This site is partly in Suffolk}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000633.pdf Citation] |The site is designated mainly because of its open [[Carr (landform)|carr fen]] communities, although further interest is provided by areas of carr woodland and meadows. [[Calcareous]] fen flora include [[Schoenus nigricans|black bog rush]], [[saw sedge]], [[purple moor grass]] and [[fen orchid]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000633.pdf |title=Blo' Norton and Thelnetham Fens citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=9 July 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508222742/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/1000633.pdf |archivedate=8 May 2014 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Booton Common]] | [[File:Booton Common - geograph.org.uk - 756000.jpg|100px|alt=Booton Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 8.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000657&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Booton Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.763|1.129|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Booton Common}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 112 230}} |[[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]],{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/booton-common|title=Booton Common |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=21 May 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] |{{Nature on the map|1000657}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000657.pdf Citation] |The common has diverse habitats, including wet [[calcareous]] fen grassland, acid heath, tall fen, [[alder]] woodland and a stream. Wet hollows are floristically rich and there are a variety of breeding birds.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000657.pdf |title= Booton Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 6 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Boughton Fen]] | [[File:View south from White Bridge - geograph.org.uk - 397850.jpg|100px|alt=Boughton Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 15.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000663&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Boughton Fen |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=15 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord| 52.583|0.534|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Boughton Fen }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 718 014}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000663}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000663.pdf Citation] |This valley in a tributary of the [[River Wissey]] is covered by tall fen over most of the site, together with areas of scrub which provide a habitat for breeding birds. There are many uncommon species of moths, including the rare ''[[Perizoma sagittaria]]''.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000663.pdf |title=Boughton Fen citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 6 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bramerton Pits]] | [[File:Bramerton Pits.jpg|100px|alt=Bramerton Pits]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000688&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Bramerton Pits |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=15 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.603|1.389 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bramerton Pits }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 296 060}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1161 |title= Bramerton (Pleistocene Vertebrata) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}}{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=608 |title=Bramerton (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1000688}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000688.pdf Citation] |The site is composed of two disused gravel pits which are important for the study of the [[Lower Pleistocene]]. Bramerton Common Pit is the [[Type locality (geology)|type site]] of the [[Norwich Crag Formation]] and Blakes Pit is the type site of the [[Bramertonian Stage]]. Both pits have yielded rich, mainly marine vertebrate fossils.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000688.pdf |title=Bramerton Pits citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 9 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Breckland Farmland]] | [[File:Fieldbarn Drove - geograph.org.uk - 397673.jpg|100px|alt=Breckland Farmland]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 13,394.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000442&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Breckland Farmland |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord|52.435|0.641 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Breckland Farmland}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 796 852}} |[[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|2000442}}{{efn|name=suffolk}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000442.pdf Citation] |The site is designated an SSSI for its internationally important population of [[Eurasian stone-curlew|stone-curlews]]. These birds nest in March on bare ground in cultivated land with very short vegetation. Fields with sugar beet and vegetables and no recreational disturbance are preferred.{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000442.pdf |title=Breckland Farmland citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508223127/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000442.pdf |archivedate=8 May 2014 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Breckland Forest]] | [[File:Wangford Warren - geograph.org.uk - 514541.jpg|100px|alt=Breckland Forest ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 18,126.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000443&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Breckland Forest |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Brandon, Suffolk|Brandon]]
{{coord|52.452|0.680 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Breckland Forest }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 822 872}} |[[Local Nature Reserve|LNR]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|2000443}}{{efn|name=suffolk}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000443.pdf Citation] |The forest has breeding [[Woodlark]]s and [[nightjar]]s in internationally important numbers, and several nationally rare vascular plants and invertebrates on the [[IUCN Red List of Threatened Species]]. There are also geological sites which provide evidence of the environmental and human history of East Anglia during the [[Middle Pleistocene]].{{cite web |url=http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000443.pdf |title=Breckland Forest citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=23 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140508223510/http://www.sssi.naturalengland.org.uk/citation/citation_photo/2000443.pdf |archivedate=8 May 2014 |df=}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Breydon Water]] | [[File:Halvergate Fleet reaches Breydon Water - geograph.org.uk - 652626.jpg|100px|alt=Breydon Water]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 514.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000454&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Breydon Water |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Great Yarmouth]]
{{coord|52.605|1.680 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Breydon Water}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 493 072}} |[[Local Nature Reserve|LNR]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1008804&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Breydon Water |series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England |accessdate= 21 May 2018}} [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]],{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK11008&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Breydon Water | series= Ramsar Site|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 25 May 2018}} [[RSPB]],{{cite web|url= https://www.rspb.org.uk/reserves-and-events/reserves-a-z/berney-marshes-breydon-water|title= Berney Marshes and Breydon Water |publisher=Royal Society for the Protection of Birds| accessdate= 6 June 2018}} [[Special Protection Area|SPA]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK9009181&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Breydon Water | series=Special Protection Areass|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1000454}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000454.pdf Citation] |This inland tidal estuary has large areas of mud at low tide, and it provides an ample food supply for migrating and wintering wildfowl and waders. There are nationally important numbers of several species of wintering wildfowl, including rare species.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000454.pdf|title=Breydon Water citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 6 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bridgham and Brettenham Heaths]] | [[File:Brettenham Heath National Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 601166.jpg|100px|alt=Brettenham Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 439.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003078&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Bridgham and Brettenham Heaths |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.442|0.828 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bridgham and Brettenham Heaths }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 923 864}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, p. 132 [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006023&SiteName=brett&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Brettenham Heath | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 25 May 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1003078}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003078.pdf Citation] |The dominant plants on this dry acidic heath are [[Calluna vulgaris|heather]] and [[wavy hair-grass]]. There are also areas of scrub and woodland. The site supports many species of breeding birds, including [[Eurasian curlew|common curlews]] and [[nightjar]]s.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003078.pdf |title=Bridgham and Brettenham Heaths citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 7 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{sortname|The |Brinks, Northwold|The Brinks, Northwold}} | [[File:The Brinks, Northwold 3.jpg|100px|alt=The Brinks, Northwold]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 16.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000025&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: The Brinks, Northwold |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Thetford]]
{{coord|52.528|0.586 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= The Brinks, Northwold}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 755 954}} | |{{Nature on the map|2000025}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000025.pdf Citation] |These unimproved meadows have areas of tall herbs and grassland grazed by cattle and sheep. There are also areas of woodland and several ponds. More than 140 flowering plants have been recorded, including [[ green-winged orchid]], [[black knapweed]] and [[pepper saxifrage]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000025.pdf |title=The Brinks, Northwold citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 September 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Briton's Lane Gravel Pit]] | [[File:Briton's Lane Gravel Pit 3.jpg|100px|alt=Briton's Lane Gravel Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 21.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001319&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Briton's Lane Gravel Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Sheringham]]
{{coord|52.926|1.225 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Briton's Lane Gravel Pit}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 169 414}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=605 |title= Briton`s Lane Gravel Pit (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1001319}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001319.pdf Citation] |This working quarry exposes gravel and sand derived from melting ice at the end of the [[Anglian stage|Anglian]] glaciation around 425,000 years ago.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001319.pdf |title=Briton's Lane Gravel Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 20 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Broad Fen, Dilham]] | [[File:Alder swamp, Broad Fen, Dilham, Norfolk - geograph.org.uk - 315278.jpg|100px|alt=Broad Fen, Dilham]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 38.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000759&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Broad Fen, Dilham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[North Walsham]]
{{coord|52.774|1.471 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Broad Fen, Dilham}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 342 253}} |[[Ramsar site|Ramsar]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1000759}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000759.pdf Citation] |This site's diverse habitats include fen, [[Carr (landform)|carr woodland]], open water and fen meadows. The open water includes ponds which were dug to attract wildfowl, a stretch of the [[North Walsham & Dilham Canal|Dilham Canal]] and dykes. Aquatic plants include [[Utricularia vulgaris|bladderwort]] and [[Nymphaea alba|white water lily]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000759.pdf |title=Broad Fen, Dilham citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 7 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Broome Heath Pit]] | [[File:Broome Heath Pit 4.jpg|100px|alt=Broome Heath Pit ]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 1.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000159&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Broome Heath Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Bungay]]
{{coord|52.473|1.454 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Broome Heath Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 347 917}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=607 |title= Broome Heath (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} [[Local Nature Reserve|LNR]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1421545&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title= Designated Sites View: Broome Heath |series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England |accessdate= 21 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|2000159}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000159.pdf Citation] |This site exposes rocks dating to the [[Wolstonian Stage|Wolstonian glaciation]] between around 350,000 and 130,000 years ago. It provides the only surviving exposure of the Broome Terrace, the flood plain of an ancient river. [[Ice wedge]]s and fossils of Arctic flora and fauna indicate a [[tundra]] environment.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000159.pdf |title=Broome Heath Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bryant's Heath, Felmingham]] | [[File:Bryant's Heath.jpg|100px|alt=Bryant's Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 17.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000770&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Bryant's Heath, Felmingham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[North Walsham]]
{{coord|52.814|1.349 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Bryant's Heath, Felmingham}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 258 293}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000770}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000770.pdf Citation] |Most of this site is dry acidic heath on glacial sands, but there are also areas of wet heath, fen and [[Carr (landform)|carr woodland]]. Several unusual mosses and lichens have been recorded in wetter areas.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000770.pdf |title=Bryant's Heath, Felmingham citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 7 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Bure Broads and Marshes]] | [[File:Bank erosion, River Bure - geograph.org.uk - 690478.jpg|100px|alt=Bure Broads and Marshes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 741.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000880&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View:Bure Broads and Marshes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.690|1.473 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Bure Broads and Marshes }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 348 159}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 55–56, 209 [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006026&SiteName=bure&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Bure Marshes | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 25 May 2018}} [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]],{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/cockshoot-broad |title= Cockshoot Broad |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 21 May 2018}}{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/ranworth-broad |title= Ranworth Broad |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=21 May 2018}} [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1000880}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000880.pdf Citation] |This is described by [[Natural England]] as a "nationally and internationally important wetland complex", which is situated on fenland peats in the floodplain of the [[River Bure]]. A notable feature is an extensive area of swamp [[alder carr]] on unstable peats and mud. There are a number of rare bird and butterfly species.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000880.pdf |title=Bure Broads and Marshes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 7 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Burgh Common and Muckfleet Marshes]] | [[File:Burgh Common and Muckfleet Marshes 3.jpg|100px|alt=Burgh Common and Muckfleet Marshes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 121.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001400&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Burgh Common and Muckfleet Marshes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|FP | [[Great Yarmouth]]
{{coord|52.657|1.606 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Burgh Common and Muckfleet Marshes}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 440 127}} |[[Ramsar site|Ramsar]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1001400}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001400.pdf Citation] |The [[Muck Fleet]], a tributary of the [[River Bure]], runs through this wetland site, which is traditionally managed by grazing and mowing. Habitats include tall fen, fen meadows and drainage dykes. There are rare plants and invertebrates, such as the [[Papilio machaon|swallowtail butterfly]] and the freshwater snail ''[[Anisus vorticulus]]''.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001400.pdf |title= Burgh Common and Muckfleet Marshes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 19 August 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Buxton Heath]] | [[File:Buxton Heath Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 519146.jpg|100px|alt=Buxton Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 67.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001445&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Buxton Heath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.749|1.220 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Buxton Heath}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 174 217}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, p. 215 [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] |{{Nature on the map|1001445}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001445.pdf Citation] |This site has areas of dry acidic heath on glacial sands, but the main ecological interest lies in the [[mire]] along the valley of a small stream. There are a number of rare relict mosses, liverworts and fungi, and uncommon invertebrates include one species not previously recorded in Britain.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001445.pdf |title=Buxton Heath citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 7 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|C}}[[Caistor St Edmund Chalk Pit]] | [[File:Chalk pit, Caistor St Edmund (aerial) - geograph.org.uk - 40516.jpg|100px|alt=Caistor St Edmund Chalk Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 23.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001465&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Caistor St. Edmund Chalk Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.595|1.306|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Caistor St. Edmund Chalk Pit }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 240 048}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=218|title=Caistor St Edmund Chalk Pit (Cenomanian, Turonian, Senonian, Maastrichtian) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}}{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2172 |title= Caistor St Edmund Pit (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1001465}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001465.pdf Citation] |This site provides the best exposure of the late [[Campanian]] Beeston Chalk, around 75 million years ago. It is very fossiliferous, with many [[mollusc]]s and [[sea urchin]]s.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001465.pdf |title=Caistor St Edmund Chalk Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 7 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Calthorpe Broad]] | [[File:View to Calthorpe Broad - geograph.org.uk - 578841.jpg|100px|alt=Calthorpe Broad]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 43.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001498&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Calthorpe Broad |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.777|1.573 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Calthorpe Broad }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 411 259}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 172–73, 210 [[national nature reserve|NNR]],{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006984&SiteName=calthor&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Calthorpe Broad |series=National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=28 May 2018}} [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1001498}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001498.pdf Citation] |This [[The Broads|broad]] has diverse fauna and flora. Water plants include [[Hippuris vulgaris|mare's-tail]], [[water violet]], [[ blunt-leaved pondweed]], [[spiked water-milfoil]], [[Isolepis fluitans|floating scirpus]], [[Nuphar lutea|yellow water-lily]] and the nationally scarce [[Stratiotes aloides|water soldier]].{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001498.pdf |title=Calthorpe Broad citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 25 October 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Cantley Marshes]] | [[File:Ditch across Cantley Marshes - geograph.org.uk - 1117708.jpg|100px|alt=Cantley Marshes ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 272.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000157&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Cantley Marshes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=16 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.582|1.497 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Cantley Marshes}}

Invertebrates include two nationally rare dragonflies, and the marshes have several important breeding bird species and an internationally important population of wintering wigeon.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000157.pdf |title=Cantley Marshes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 8 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Castle Acre Common]] | [[File:River Nar west of Castle Acre - geograph.org.uk - 604734.jpg|100px|alt=Castle Acre Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 17.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005965&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Castle Acre Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[King's Lynn]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TL 998 879}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003780}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003780.pdf Citation] |The importance of this site lies in its [[pingo]]s, [[periglacial]] ground ice depressions, and it has many scarce species of beetles. There are also areas of chalk grassland and floristically rich fen.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003780.pdf |title=East Harling Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 8 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[East Runton Cliffs]] | [[File:Cliff erosion - geograph.org.uk - 792987.jpg|100px|alt=East Runton Cliffs]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 20.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001372&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: East Runton Cliffs |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Cromer]]
{{coord|52.938|1.271 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= East Runton Cliffs}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 199 429}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1162 |title= East Runton (Pleistocene Vertebrata) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=612 |title= East Runton (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1001372}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001372.pdf Citation] |The foreshore exposes [[Lower Pleistocene]] sediments, including large blocks of glacitectonic (transported by ice) chalk. There are many fossils, including extinct horse, rhinoceros, and elephant.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001372.pdf |title=East Runton Cliffs citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 9 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[East Ruston Common]] | [[File:East Ruston Allotment - geograph.org.uk - 785909.jpg|100px|alt=East Ruston Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 39.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001693&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: East Ruston Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.799|1.473 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=East Ruston Common }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 342 280}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001693}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001693.pdf Citation] |This is an area of unimproved fen, heath and [[Carr (landform)|carr woodland]] in the valley of a tributary of the [[River Ant]]. it is the only known English locality for the rare spider, ''[[acanthophyma gowerensis]]'', and it also has another nationally rare spider, ''[[hygrolycosa rubrofasciata]]''.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001693.pdf |title=East Ruston Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 9 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[East Walton and Adcock's Common]] | [[File:East Walton common - geograph.org.uk - 150413.jpg|100px|alt=East Walton Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 62.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001267&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: East Walton and Adcock's Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord|52.715|0.569 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=East Walton and Adcock's Common }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 736 161}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2329 |title= East Walton Common (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] |{{Nature on the map|1001267}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001267.pdf Citation] |These commons have [[periglacial]] depressions separated by chalk ridges. The habitats include chalk grassland, springs, open water and scrub. The grasses and herbs are diverse with up to thirty-two species per square metre, and the rich invertebrate fauna includes seven [[Red Data Book]] and seventy-nine nationally rare species.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001267.pdf |title=East Walton and Adcock's Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 9 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[East Winch Common]] | [[File:East Winch Common - geograph.org.uk - 549715.jpg|100px|alt=East Winch Common ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 26.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001708&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: East Winch Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord|52.713|0.515 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=East Winch Common }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 700 158}} |[[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]]{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/east-winch-common|title= East Winch Common |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 21 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1001708}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001708.pdf Citation] |This site is mainly wet acid heath on peat, and it is dominated by [[Calluna vulgaris|heather]] and [[cross-leaved heath]]. There are many wet hollows, which have diverse fen and [[mire]] flora, and areas of young woodland.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001708.pdf |title=East Winch Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 10 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[East Wretham Heath]] | [[File:East Wretham Heath Nature Reserve - geograph.org.uk - 337337.jpg|100px|alt=East Wretham Heath]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 141.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001738&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: East Wretham Heath |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Thetford]]
{{coord|52.458|0.808 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= East Wretham Heath}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 909 882}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, p. 131 [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]],{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/east-wretham-heath|title=East Wretham Heath |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=21 May 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1001738}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001738.pdf Citation] |The principal ecological interest of this site lies in areas of Breckland grassland and two [[Mere (lake)|meres]], which are supplied by ground water, and fluctuate irregularly. These conditions have led to unusual plants communities which are tolerant of alternate wetting and drying, such as [[reed canary grass]] and [[amphibious bistort]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001738.pdf |title=East Wretham Heath citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 11 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Eaton Chalk Pit]] | [[File:Eaton Chalk Pit fence.jpg|100px|alt=Fence around Eaton Chalk Pit]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 0.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001757&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Eaton Chalk Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.610|1.261|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Eaton Chalk Pit}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 209 064}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001757}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001757.pdf Citation] |These former chalk mines are used by hibernating bats and the site has been monitored over a long period for research into bat ecology. Up to 40 bats use the mines and the main species are [[Daubenton's]], [[Natterer's]] and [[brown long-eared bat]]s.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001757.pdf |title=Eaton Chalk Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 7 August 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Edgefield Little Wood]] |[[File:Edgefield Little Wood 4.jpg|100px|alt=Edgefield Little Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 5.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002065&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Edgefield Little Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Melton Constable]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TG 107 341}} | |{{Nature on the map|1002065}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002065.pdf Citation] |This is [[coppice with standards]] ancient woodland on acidic sands and gravels. [[Oak]]s which have been coppiced in the past have [[Living stump|stools]] which are so tall that the wood resembles [[High forest (woodland)|high forest]]. It is surrounded by ancient boundary banks.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002065.pdf |title=Edgefield Little Wood citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 24 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Elm Road Field, Thetford]] | [[File:Elm Road Field, Thetford 6.jpg|100px|alt=Elm Road Field]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 5.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000085&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Elm Road Field, Thetford |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Thetford]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TL 859 815}} | |{{Nature on the map|2000085}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000085.pdf Citation] |This area of open space has grassland with a rich flora. There are a number of uncommon plants, including the nationally endangered [[field wormwood]] and the nationally scarce [[ sickle medick]] and [[tower mustard]]. There are two mature [[scots pine]] hedges.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000085.pdf |title=Elm Road Field, Thetford citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|F}}[[Felbrigg Woods]] | [[File:Felbrigg Park Great Wood, inviting but just a little swampy - geograph.org.uk - 509905.jpg|100px|alt=Felbrigg Woods]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 164.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001767&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Felbrigg Woods |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.913|1.262 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Felbrigg Woods }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 194 400}} |[[AONB]], [[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, p. 60 [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|NT]],{{cite web|url=https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/felbrigg-hall-gardens-and-estate |title= Felbrigg Hall, Gardens and Estate |publisher=National Trust| accessdate= 30 May 2018}} [[RHPG]]{{cite web|url= https://historicengland.org.uk/listing/the-list/list-entry/1000185 |title= Felbrigg Hall |series =Register of Historic Parks and Gardens of Special Historic Interest in England|publisher = Historic England|accessdate= 11 June 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1001767}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001767.pdf Citation] |Ancient trees in this wood have more than fifty species of lichen, including several which are rare in [[East Anglia]]. Many of them are indicators of ancient undisturbed woodland. The trees are mainly [[Fagus sylvatica|beech]] which have been [[pollarded]] many years ago, and have massive [[Living stump|stools]] and [[Trunk (botany)|boles]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001767.pdf |title=Felbrigg Woods citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 11 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Field Barn Heaths, Hilborough]] | [[File:Field Barn Heaths, Hilborough 3.jpg|100px|alt=Field Barn Heaths, Hilborough]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|17.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001124&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Field Barn Heaths, Hilborough |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Thetford]]

There are also areas of ungrazed grassland and [[quercus robur|oak]] and [[Crataegus monogyna|hawthorn]] woodland.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001124.pdf |title=Field Barn Heaths, Hilborough citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 September 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Flordon Common]] | [[File:Flordon Common - geograph.org.uk - 163528.jpg|100px|alt=Flordon Common ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert|9.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001788&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Flordon Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]

On higher ground there is chalk grassland, which is traditionally managed by grazing, allowing the survival of many locally rare plants.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001788.pdf |title=Flordon Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 11 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Forncett Meadows]] | [[File:Forncett Meadows 5.jpg|100px|alt=Forncett Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 5.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000372&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Forncett Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|FP | [[Norwich]]

Flora in the fen grassland include [[purple moor-grass]], [[black bog rush]], [[purple small-reed]] and [[blunt-flowered rush]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002450.pdf |title=Foulden Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 11 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Foxley Wood]] | [[File:Path in Foxley Wood - geograph.org.uk - 1692074.jpg|100px|alt=Foxley Wood ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 124.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002457&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Foxley Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Dereham]]

Scattered ancient trees have a wide variety of [[Epiphyte|epiphytic]] lichens, including some which are locally rare. There are a number of natural ponds with diverse invertebrate fauna.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000352.pdf |title=Fritton Common, Morningthorpe citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 29 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|G}}[[Gawdyhall Big Wood, Harleston]] | [[File:Gawdyhall Big Wood Harleston 4.jpg|100px|alt=Gawdyhall Big Wood Harleston]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 29.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004030&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Gawdyhall Big Wood, Harleston |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Redenhall with Harleston|Harleston]]

The ground flora is especially diverse around the hornbeams and on wet rides.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004030.pdf |title=Gawdyhall Big Wood, Harleston citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 29 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Geldeston Meadows]] | [[File:Geldeston Meadows 3.jpg|100px|alt=Geldeston Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 14.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001931&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Geldeston Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Beccles]]

Most of the site is wet grassland which is dominated by [[sweet vernal grass]], [[common quaking grass]] and [[crested dog's-tail]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001931.pdf |title=Geldeston Meadows citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Glandford (Hurdle Lane)]] | [[File:Glandford (Hurdle Lane) 2.jpg|100px|alt=Glandford (Hurdle Lane)]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 9.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002247&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Glandford (Hurdle Lane) |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Holt, Norfolk|Holt]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TG 053 415}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2335 |title= Glandford (Hurdle Lane) (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1002247}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002247.pdf Citation] |This is a working quarry in the valley of the [[River Glaven]]. It has a complex sequence of deposits formed by [[Pleistocene]] glaciers, with [[till]], [[lacustrine]] [[calcareous]] silts, sands and coarse gravels, which throw light on the glacial history of the area.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002247.pdf |title=Glandford (Hurdle Lane) citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 20 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Glandford (Letheringsett Road)]] | [[File:Glandford (Letheringsett Road) 4.jpg|100px|alt=Glandford (Letheringsett Road)]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 1.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005462&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Glandford (Letheringsett Road) |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Holt, Norfolk|Holt]]
{{coord|52.928|1.037 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Glandford (Letheringsett Road)}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 042 410}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2332 |title= Glandford (Letheringsett Road) (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1005462}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005462.pdf Citation] |This site is important because it has mounds of gravel and [[till]] which can help to show whether the North Norfolk till plain is the result of [[Pleistocene]] glacial deposition or is the residue of the erosion of a former more extensive area of gravel.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005462.pdf |title=Glandford (Letheringsett Road) citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 20 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Gooderstone Warren]] | [[File:Gooderstone Warren.jpg|100px|alt=Gooderstone Warren]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 21.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001236&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Gooderstone Warren |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Thetford]]
{{coord|52.577|0.645 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Gooderstone Warren }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 793 010}} |[[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1001236}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001236.pdf Citation] |This sandy site has soils which range from acid to [[calcareous]], resulting in a variety of grassland types. There is a pit at the north end which has flora including [[Primula veris|cowslips]] and the uncommon [[Astragalus danicus|purple milk vetch]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001236.pdf |title=Gooderstone Warren citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 September 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Great Cressingham Fen]] | [[File:Great Cressingham Fen 2.jpg|100px|alt=Great Cressingham Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 14.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000561&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Great Cressingham Fen |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Thetford]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TF 847 022}} |[[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] |{{Nature on the map|1000561}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000561.pdf Citation] |This [[calcareous]] spring-fed valley has a variety of vegetation types, ranging from dry unimproved grassland on high slopes to tall fen where the springs emerge at the valley bottom. There is a diverse range of flora, including some uncommon species. Plants in the valley bottom include [[water mint]] and [[southern marsh orchid]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000561.pdf |title=Great Cressingham Fen citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 September 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Great Yarmouth North Denes]] | [[File:Tracks in the sand, Great Yarmouth - geograph.org.uk - 771299.jpg|100px|alt=Great Yarmouth North Denes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 100.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006347&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Great Yarmouth North Denes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Great Yarmouth]]
{{coord| 52.632|1.737|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Great Yarmouth North Denes}}

Five species of bat use re-excavated Neolithic flint-mines for winter roosting.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002530.pdf |title=Grimes Graves citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 11 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Grimston Warren Pit]] | [[File:Grimston Warren Pit 1.jpg|100px|alt=Grimston Warren Pit ]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 6.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000172&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Grimston Warren Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[King's Lynn]]

It has yielded [[ammonite]]s which date to the [[Hauterivian]] age around 130 million years ago.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000172.pdf |title=Grimston Warren Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 1 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Gunton Park Lake]] | [[File:Gunton Park Lake.jpg|100px|alt=Gunton Park Lake]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 18.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001287&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Gunton Park Lake |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TG 220 345}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001287}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001287.pdf Citation] |This artificial lake has the largest flock of post-breeding [[gadwall]] in Britain, and more than 500 birds have sometimes been recorded in September. Wintering wildfowl include [[Eurasian teal|teal]], [[mallard]], [[Northern shoveler|shoveler]], [[shelduck]] and [[goosander]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001287.pdf |title=Gunton Park Lake citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 28 October 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|H}}[[Hall Farm Fen, Hemsby]] | [[File:Hall Farm Fen, Hemsby 2.jpg|100px|alt=Hall Farm Fen, Hemsby]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 9.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002215&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hall Farm Fen, Hemsby |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Great Yarmouth]]

The diverse ground flora includes some uncommon species.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001913.pdf |title=Hedenham Wood citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hilgay Heronry]] | [[File:Hilgay Heronry 1.jpg|100px|alt=Hilgay Heronry ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 1.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001293&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hilgay Heronry |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Downham Market]]
