{{gbmappingsmall|TF 862 428}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=728 |title= Holkham Brick Pits (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1002649}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002649.pdf Citation] |This is the best site displaying the Hunstanton Till, a glacial deposit dating the [[last glacial period]], between 115,000 and 11,700 years ago. This is the furthest the ice reached in [[East Anglia]] during the [[Last Glacial Maximum]], around 26,000 years ago.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002649.pdf |title= Holkham Brickpits citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 10 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Holly Farm Meadow, Wendling]] | [[File:Holly Farm Meadow, Wendling.jpg|100px|alt=Holly Farm Meadow, Wendling]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 2.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002634&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Holly Farm Meadow, Wendling |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Dereham]]
{{coord|52.680|0.862 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Holly Farm Meadow, Wendling}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 936 130}} | |{{Nature on the map|1002634}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002634.pdf Citation] |This meadow in the valley of the [[River Wensum]] has a line of [[calcareous]] springs which supports fen grassland which has diverse flora. {{gbmappingsmall|TF 932 143}} |[[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]]{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/honeypot-wood|title=Honeypot Wood |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=21 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1002724}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002724.pdf Citation] |This is an ancient [[coppice]]d wood on [[calcareous]] soil. It has a rich ground layer, which is dominated by [[dog's mercury]], and other flora include [[greater butterfly-orchid]] and [[broad-leaved helleborine]]. A total of 208 plant species have been recorded.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002724.pdf|title=Honeypot Wood citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 12 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hooks Well Meadows, Great Cressingham]] | [[File:Hooks Well Meadows, Great Cressingham 3.jpg|100px|alt=Hooks Well Meadows, Great Cressingham]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 15.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001149&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hooks Well Meadows, Great Cressingham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Thetford]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TF 837 011}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001149}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001149.pdf Citation] |This site has a long history of traditional management. The diverse habitats include fen meadow, herb-rich wet grassland, acidic [[Seep (hydrology)|flushes]], dry [[calcareous]] grassland and wet [[Alnus glutinosa|alder]] woodland, which has carpets of [[sphagnum]] mosses.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001149.pdf |title=Hooks Well Meadows, Great Cressingham citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 September 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Horningtoft Wood]] | [[File:Horningtoft Wood 4.jpg|100px|alt=Horningtoft Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 8.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002751&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Horningtoft Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Dereham]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TF 948 237}} | |{{Nature on the map|1002751}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002751.pdf Citation] |This ancient [[coppice with standards]] wood on [[boulder clay]] has exceptionally diverse ground flora with several rare species. There are scattered mature [[quercus robur|oaks]] and the main coppiced species are [[Corylus avellana|hazel]], [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]] and [[Acer campestre|maple]]. The ground flora is dominated by [[dog's mercury]] on heavy soils and [[bramble]] on lighter ones.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002751.pdf |title=Horningtoft Wood citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 26 August 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Horse Wood, Mileham]] | [[File:View towards Horse Wood - geograph.org.uk - 607128.jpg|100px|alt=Horse Wood ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 7.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004051&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Horse Wood, Mileham|series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord| 52.731|0.844|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Horse Wood, Mileham}}

There are wide and wet [[Bridle path|rides]] which have plants such as [[herb paris]], [[Valerian (herb)|valerian]] and [[water mint]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004051.pdf |title=Horse Wood, Mileham citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 12 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hunstanton Cliffs]] | [[File:Cliffs-of-Hunstanton-08.JPG|100px|alt=Hunstanton Cliffs]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 4.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002810&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hunstanton Cliffs |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Hunstanton]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TF 676 420}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4177&authority=UKH13|title= Hunstanton Cliffs (Cenomanian, Turonian, Senonian, Maastrichtian) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=626 |title= Hunstanton Cliffs (Aptian-Albian) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1002810}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002810.pdf Citation] |These eroding cliffs expose a mid-[[Cretaceous]] sequence from the [[Albian]] to the succeeding [[Cenomanian]] around 100 million years ago, with exceptionally rich Albian [[ammonite]] fossils. Biological interest is provided by a colony of breeding [[fulmar]]s on the cliff face.{{cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002810.pdf |title=Hunstanton Cliffs citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 12 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Hunstanton Park Esker]] | [[File:Hunstanton Park Esker 2.jpg|100px|alt=Hunstanton Park Esker ]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 17.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006039&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hunstanton Park Eske |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Hunstanton]]

The dry conditions are favourable to reptiles such as [[viviparous lizard|common lizard]] and [[Viperidae|adder]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002812.pdf |title=Kelling Heath citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 12 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Kenninghall and Banham Fens with Quidenham Mere]] | [[File:Kenninghall and Banham Fens with Quidenham Mere 2.jpg|100px|alt=Kenninghall and Banham Fens with Quidenham Mere]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 48.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000583&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Kenninghall and Banham Fens with Quidenham Mere |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TM 380 929}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2334 |title= Leet Hill (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|2000156}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000156.pdf Citation] |This is a quarry which has a sequence of deposits dating to the [[Middle Pleistocene]], with the base of gravels laid down by a confluence of rivers, with glacial gravels above, and then a sequence of chalky sands probably also laid down by glaciers.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000156.pdf |title=Leet Hill, Kirby Cane citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Leziate, Sugar and Derby Fens]] | [[File:Sugar Fen 7.jpg|100px|alt=Sugar Fen ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 87.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002837&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Leziate, Sugar and Derby Fens |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord|52.754|0.518 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Leziate, Sugar and Derby Fens}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 700 204}} | |{{Nature on the map|1002837}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002837.pdf Citation] |These fens have extensive heaths and areas of wet acidic grassland, and there are smaller areas of damp woodland and species-rich calcareous grassland. There are many ant-hills on Derby Fen.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002837.pdf |title=Leziate, Sugar and Derby Fens citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 31 May 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Limpenhoe Meadows]] | [[File:Limpenhoe Meadows 5.jpg|100px|alt=Limpenhoe Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 12.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000609&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Limpenhoe Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TG 027 117}} | |{{Nature on the map|2000449}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000449.pdf Citation] |This area of [[calcareous]] fen and marshy grassland has a rich variety of flora. [[Black bog-rush]], [[blunt-flowered rush]] and [[purple moor-grass]] are common in the fen areas, and purple moor-grass is also abundant in the grassland, together with other plants such as [[yellow rattle]] and [[marsh pennywort]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000449.pdf |title=Mattishall Moor citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 3 September 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Middle Harling Fen]] | [[File:Middle Harling Fen 1.jpg|100px|alt=Middle Harling Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 11.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000696&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Middle Harling Fen |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.429|0.923 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Middle Harling Fen }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 988 852}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000696}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000696.pdf Citation] |This [[calcareous]] valley fen has several springs and a wide variety of types of grassland, including both wet and dry communities. There are uncommon flora such as [[Ophioglossum vulgatum|adder's tongue]] and [[yellow rattle]], and the breeding birds are diverse.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000696.pdf |title=Middle Harling Fen citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 22 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Morston Cliff]] | [[File:Morston Cliff 1.jpg|100px|alt=Morston Cliff ]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 1.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003539&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Morston Cliff |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Wells-next-the-Sea]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TF 990 441}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=727|title= Morston Cliff (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006016&SiteName=blakeney&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Blakeney | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 1 June 2018}} [[National Trust for Places of Historic Interest or Natural Beauty|NT]]{{cite web|url= https://www.nationaltrust.org.uk/blakeney-national-nature-reserve |title= Blakeney National Nature Reserve |publisher=National Trust|accessdate= 1 June 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1003539}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003539.pdf Citation] |This key [[Pleistocene]] site has the only [[interglacial]] deposit of a raised beach in [[East Anglia]]. It is believed to be [[Ipswichian]], dating to around 125,000 years ago, and is overlain by glacial deposits of the late [[Devensian]] Hunstanton Till.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003539.pdf |title=Morston Cliff citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 10 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Mundesley Cliffs]] | [[File:MundesleyBeachInSummer(StephenCraven)Aug2006.jpg|100px|alt=Mundesley Cliffs]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 29.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003572&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Mundesley Cliffs |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[North Walsham]]
{{coord|52.869|1.452 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Mundesley Cliffs}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 324 358}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=614 |title= Mundesley (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1003572}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003572.pdf Citation] |The cliffs on this site display some of the best marine and freshwater deposits dating to the [[Cromerian]] interglacial, and to the early stages of the succeeding [[Anglian glaciation]], which started around 478,000 years ago.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003572.pdf |title=Mundesley Cliffs citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 12 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|N}}[[Narborough Railway Line|Narborough Railway Embankment ]] | [[File:Narborough railway walk - geograph.org.uk - 630656.jpg|100px|alt=Narborough Railway Embankment ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 7.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000284&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Narborough Railway Embankment |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|PL | [[King's Lynn]]

There is also a variety of mosses and molluscs.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000284.pdf |title=Narborough Railway Embankment citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 13 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[New Buckenham Common]] | [[File:New Buckenham Common - geograph.org.uk - 433216.jpg|100px|New Buckenham Common ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 20.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004142&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: New Buckenham Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 16 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]

finest in Europe. The barn also has colonies of several other bats.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000408.pdf|title=Paston Great Barn citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 13 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Poplar Farm Meadows, Langley]] | [[File:Poplar Farm Meadows, Langley 1.jpg|100px|alt=Poplar Farm Meadows, Langley]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 7.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003638&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Poplar Farm Meadows, Langley |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TF 982 120}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 213–14 [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]],{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/scarning-fen |title= Scarning Fen |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=21 May 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] |{{Nature on the map|1003694}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003694.pdf Citation] |These are valleys with [[calcareous]] fens on peat with an exceptionally diverse flora, including uncommon mosses and [[liverwort]]s. Insects include the nationally rare [[small red damselfly]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003694.pdf |title=Potter and Scarning Fens, East Dereham citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 13 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Potter's Carr, Cranworth]] | [[File:Potter's Carr, Cranworth 2.jpg|100px|alt=Potter's Carr, Cranworth]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 6.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003677&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Potter's Carr, Cranworth |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Thetford]]
{{coord| 52.598|0.922|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Potter's Carr, Cranworth }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 980 040}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003677}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003677.pdf Citation] |This area of [[alder carr]] and wet pasture is on the bank of the [[River Blackwater, Norfolk|River Blackwater]]. The diverse flora of the carr is typical of ancient woodland, with plants such as [[dog's mercury]] and [[moschatel]]. Wintering birds include [[water rail]]s.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003677.pdf |title=Potter's Carr, Cranworth citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 3 September 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Priory Meadows, Hickling]] | [[File:View north across marshland - geograph.org.uk - 578844.jpg|100px|alt=Priory Meadows, Hickling]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 23.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001026&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Priory Meadows, Hickling |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.771|1.579 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Priory Meadows, Hickling}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 415 253}} |[[Ramsar site|Ramsar]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1001026}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001026.pdf Citation] |This grassland on damp and acidic peat soil is managed traditionally, and it has a rich and diverse flora with herbs such as [[Potentilla erecta|tormentil]] and [[marsh cinquefoil]]. There is also a network of dykes with aquatic plants.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001026.pdf |title=Priory Meadows, Hickling citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 13 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Pulham Market Big Wood]] | [[File:Pulham Market Big Wood 1.jpg|100px|alt=Pulham Market Big Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 4.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001412&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Pulham Market Big Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Diss]]
{{coord| 52.459|1.244|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Pulham Market Big Wood }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 205 895}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001412}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001412.pdf Citation] |This ancient coppice wood on [[boulder clay]] is probably the last fragment of a much larger area of woodland. The standard trees are mature [[pedunculate oak]]s and the coppice layer is very overgrown. The ground flora is dominated by [[Rubus fruticosus|bramble]], [[Lonicera periclymenum|honeysuckle]] and [[Pteridium aquilinum|bracken]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001412.pdf |title=Pulham Market Big Woo citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 29 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|R}}[[Redgrave and Lopham Fens]] | [[File:Redgrave and South Lopham Fen.jpg|100px|alt=Redgrave and Lopham Fens]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 127.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003726&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Redgrave and Lopham Fens |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Diss]]
{{coord|52.376|1.001 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Redgrave and Lopham Fens}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 049 796}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, p. 214 [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006122&SiteName=redgrave&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Redgrave and Lopham Fen | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 1 June 2018}} [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK11056&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Redgrave & South Lopham Fens | series= Ramsar Site|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 1 June 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Suffolk Wildlife Trust|SWT]]{{cite web |url=http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/redgrave |title=Redgrave and Lopham Fens |publisher=Suffolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=1 May 2017 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170303044947/http://www.suffolkwildlifetrust.org/redgrave |archivedate=3 March 2017 |df=}} |{{Nature on the map|1003726}}{{efn|name=suffolk}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003726.pdf Citation] |This spring-fed valley at the head of the [[River Waveney]] has several different types of fen vegetation. There are aquatic plants such as [[Utricularia vulgaris|bladderwort]], [[fen pondweed]] and [[Charophytes]], all of which are indicators of low levels of pollution. The site has the only known British population of [[fen raft spider]]s.{{cite web |url=https://necmsi.esdm.co.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003726.pdf |title=Redgrave and Lopham Fens citation |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest |publisher=Natural England |accessdate=7 June 2017}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Ringstead Downs]] | [[File:Ringstead Downs 10.jpg|100px|alt=Ringstead Downs ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 6.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003747&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Ringstead Downs |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Hunstanton]]
{{coord| 52.931|0.514|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Ringstead Downs}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 691 400}} |[[AONB]], [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]]{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/ringstead-downs |title= Ringstead Downs |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 21 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1003747}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003747.pdf Citation] |This is a dry chalk valley which was carved out by glacial meltwaters It is species-rich as it has never been ploughed, and it is the largest surviving area of chalk downland surviving in the county. The butterflies are diverse.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003747.pdf |title=Ringstead Downs citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 31 May 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[River Nar]] | [[File:Along the River Nar on the Nar Valley Way - geograph.org.uk - 1638964.jpg|100px|alt=River Nar ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 212.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006323&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: River Nar |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord| 52.711|0.682|type:landmark_region:GB|name=River Nar }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 813 160}} | |{{Nature on the map|1006323}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1006323.pdf Citation] |The upper Nar has 78 river and bankside species of plants, including 5 [[Potamogeton|pondweeds]] and 8 [[bryophyte]]s. The lower reaches which flow through a flood plain are more sluggish. The most common fish are [[brown trout]], [[Northern pike|pike]], [[Rutilus rutilus|roach]] and [[Anguilla Anguilla|eel]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1006323.pdf |title=River Nar citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 13 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[River Wensum]] | [[File:A winding river - geograph.org.uk - 894014.jpg|100px|alt=River Wensum]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 386.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006328&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: River Wensum |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Dereham]]
{{coord|52.766|0.967 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= River Wensum}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 003 228}} |[[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0012647&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: River Wensum | series=Special Areas of Conservation|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 1 June 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1006328}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1006328.pdf Citation] |This river has been selected by [[Natural England]] as an example of an enriched, calcareous lowland river running through a relatively natural corridor. It has a rich invertebrate fauna and more than 100 species of flora. The SSSI also includes two tributaries, the [[River Tat]] and the [[Langor Drain]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1006328.pdf |title=River Wensum citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 13 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Rosie Curston's Meadow, Mattishall ]] | [[File:Rosie Curston's Meadow, Mattishall.jpg|100px|alt=Rosie Curston's Meadow]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 2.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1006661&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Rosie Curston's Meadow, Mattishall |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Dereham]]
{{coord|52.669|1.017 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Rosie Curston's Meadow, Mattishall }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 041 122}} | |{{Nature on the map|1006661}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1006661.pdf Citation] |This unimproved [[calcareous]] clay meadow is managed by cattle grazing. It has over sixty grass species and a rich variety of herbs, including [[green-winged orchid]], [[Ophioglossum vulgatum|adder's tongue]], [[Ophrys apifera|bee orchid]], [[Listera ovata|twayblade]] and [[yellow rattle]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1006661.pdf |title=Rosie Curston's Meadow, Mattishall citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 23 October 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Roydon Common]] | [[File:A pathway on Roydon Common. - geograph.org.uk - 161884.jpg|100px|alt=Roydon Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 194.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003787&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Roydon Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord|52.773|0.498 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Roydon Common}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 686 224}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 130–31, 212–13 [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006628&SiteName=roydon&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Roydon Common | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 31 May 2018}} [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]],{{cite web|url=https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/roydon-common-and-grimston-warren |title= Roydon Common and Grimston Warren |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=21 May 2018}} [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK11061&SiteName=roydon&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Roydon Common | series= Ramsar Site|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 31 May 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0012801&SiteName=roydon&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Roydon Common and Dersingham Bog | series=Special Areas of Conservation|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 31 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1003787}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003787.pdf Citation] |The common is described by [[Natural England]] as "one of the best examples in Britain of a lowland mixed valley mire". It has diverse habitats, including wet acid heath, [[calcareous]] fen and dry heath on acid sands. There are rare plants, birds and insects, including the [[Sympetrum danae|black darter]] dragonfly.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003787.pdf |title=Roydon Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 31 May 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|S}}[[Scoulton Mere]] | [[File:Scoulton Mere - geograph.org.uk - 278014.jpg|100px|alt=Scoulton Mere ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 34.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003828&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Scoulton Mere |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.573|0.929 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Scoulton Mere }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 986 013}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003828}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003828.pdf Citation] |The principal ecological interest of this site lies in the swamp, fen and bog flora on islands in the mere and along the shore. The largest island, called Scoulton Heath, is mainly covered in [[sphagnum moss]], and other plants include the nationally rare [[Dryopteris cristata|crested buckler fern]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003828.pdf |title= Scoulton Mere citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 13 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sea Mere, Hingham]] | [[File:Sea Mere, Hingham Norfolk 1.JPG|100px|alt=Sea Mere, Hingham ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 36.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003834&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Sea Mere, Hingham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]
{{coord|52.570|1.001 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Sea Mere, Hingham}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 035 011}} | |{{Nature on the map|1003834}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003834.pdf Citation] |This site has a natural lake together with areas of fen, grazing marsh and woodland. The fen has a rich variety of flora including [[saw sedge]], [[marsh pennywort]], [[Lysimachia vulgaris|yellow loosestrife]], [[yellow iris]] and the rare [[green figwort]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003834.pdf|title=Sea Mere, Hingham citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 14 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Setchey SSSI|Setchey]] | [[File:Setchey SSSI 5.jpg|100px|alt=Setchey]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 33.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005803&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Setchey |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord|52.691|0.413 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Setchey}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 632 131}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2522 |title= Setchey (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1005803}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005803.pdf Citation] |This site throws light on sea level changes in the [[Holocene]], the period since the end of the [[Younger Dryas|last ice age]], 11,700 years ago. It is part of a network of [[The Fens|Fenland]] sites which allows correlation across the area.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005803.pdf |title=Setchey citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 5 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sexton Wood]] | [[File:Sexton Wood 5.jpg|100px|alt=Sexton Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 39.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003867&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Sexton Wood |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Bungay]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TM 298 916}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]]Ratcliffe, pp. 59–60 |{{Nature on the map|1003867}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003867.pdf Citation] |This ancient wood on [[boulder clay]] is mainly [[coppice with standards]], but there are some areas of [[High forest (woodland)|high forest]]. The ground flora is diverse, with [[dog's mercury]] dominant and other plants such as [[ransoms]] and [[early-purple orchid]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003867.pdf |title=Sexton Wood citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 15 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Shallam Dyke Marshes, Thurne]] | [[File:Thurne marshes - geograph.org.uk - 802588.jpg|100px|alt=Shallam Dyke Marshes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 69.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003605&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Shallam Dyke Marshes, Thurne |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Great Yarmouth]]
{{coord| 52.694|1.550|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Shallam Dyke Marshes, Thurne}}

There are a variety of water plants such as the rare [[Stratiotes aloides|water soldier]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003605.pdf |title=Shallam Dyke Marshes, Thurne citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 14 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Shelfanger Meadows]] | [[File:Shelfanger Meadows 4.jpg|100px|alt=Shelfanger Meadows]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 10.3 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000285&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Shelfanger Meadows |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Diss ]]
{{coord|52.403|1.099 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Shelfanger Meadows }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 109 828}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000285}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000285.pdf Citation] |This site in the valley of a tributary of the [[River Waveney]] is described by [[Natural England]] as "one of the most important areas of unimproved grassland in Norfolk". It has been traditionally managed by a hay cut followed by grazing for hundreds of years, and as a result its flora is rich, including uncommon species. There are also areas where springs make the grassland marshy.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000285.pdf |title=Shelfanger Meadows citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 22 July 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Sheringham and Beeston Regis Commons]] | [[File:2018-04-17 Pond, Sheringham common, Norfolk.JPG|100px|alt=Sheringham Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 24.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003902&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Sheringham and Beeston Regis Commons |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Sheringham]]
{{coord|52.934|1.219 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Sheringham and Beeston Regis Commons }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 164 422}} |[[AONB]], [[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]] [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] |{{Nature on the map|1003902}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003902.pdf Citation] |These commons have areas of dry heathland which have several species of breeding birds and reptiles, and wet fen in low lying areas where there are springs. [[Calcareous]] [[mire]]s have uncommon plants such as [[Pinguicula vulgaris|butterwort]] and [[bog pimpernel]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003902.pdf |title=Sheringham and Beeston Regis Commons citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 14 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Shotesham Common]] | [[File:Shotesham Common 9.jpg|100px|alt=Shotesham Common ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 21.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000341&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Shotesham Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TM 240 997}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000341}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000341.pdf Citation] |This site consists of traditionally managed meadows with a variety of grassland types, ranging from permanently wet marshes on the valley bottom, where a stream runs through, to drier grassland on the slopes. {{gbmappingsmall|TM 256 961}} | |{{Nature on the map|1004212}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004212.pdf Citation] |This site is composed of four ancient [[coppice with standards]] [[Carpinus betulus|hornbeam]] woods on [[boulder clay]], Shotesham Little Wood, Saxlingham Grove, Hempnall Little Wood and Winter’s Grove. There are several rare beetles and the [[Red Data Book]] parasitic herbaceous plant [[Orobanche purpurea|purple broomrape]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003919.pdf |title=Sidestrand and Trimingham Cliffs citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 14 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Smallburgh Fen]] | [[File:Smallburgh Fen (2).jpg|100px|alt=Smallburgh Fen]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 7.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004510&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Smallburgh Fen |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TL 929 956}} |[[Local Nature Reserve|LNR]], [[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 138–39 [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]],{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/thompson-common#TabsReserveTabs_TabWildlifehighlights |title= Thompson Common |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 21 June 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] |{{Nature on the map|1000249}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000249.pdf Citation] |This grassland site in the valley of a tributary of the [[River Wissey]] has a number of [[pingo]]s, damp and water filled depressions formed by the melting of ice at the end of the last glaciation. It also has a lake called Thompson Water which, together with its surrounding reedswamp, is important for breeding birds.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000249.pdf |title=Thompson Water, Carr and Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 21 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Tindall Wood, Ditchingham]] | [[File:Tindall Wood - geograph.org.uk - 473717.jpg|100px|alt=Tindall Wood ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 42.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001491&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Tindall Wood, Ditchingham |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 18 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Bungay]]
{{coord|52.489|1.426 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Tindall Wood, Ditchingham }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TM 327 934}} | |{{Nature on the map|1001491}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001491.pdf Citation] |This is one of the largest [[Carpinus betulus|hornbeam]] woods in Norfolk. It is ancient [[coppice with standards]], and the standards are [[Quercus robur|oak]], [[Fraxinus excelsior|ash]] and hornbeam, and there are several uncommon species in the ground flora.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001491.pdf |title=Tindall Wood, Ditchingham citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 21 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Trinity Broads ]] |[[File:Norfolk Broads - geograph.org.uk - 1339182.jpg|100px|alt= Trinity Broads ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 316.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S2000355&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Trinity Broads |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Great Yarmouth ]]
{{coord|52.676|1.643 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Trinity Broads }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 464 149}} |[[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]] |{{Nature on the map|2000355}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000355.pdf Citation] |The site is composed of five interconnected lakes in a side valley of the [[River Bure]], together with reedswamp, wet woodland and fen. There are nationally important numbers of breeding wildfowl, and several nationally rare invertebrates, such as the [[Papilio machaon|swallowtail butterfly]] and two [[Red Data Book]] flies.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/2000355.pdf |title=Trinity Broads citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 21 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|U}}[[Upper Thurne Broads and Marshes]] | [[File:Horsey Mere - geograph.org.uk - 222929.jpg|100px|alt=Upper Thurne Broads and Marshes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 1,185.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005779&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Upper Thurne Broads and Marshes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Norwich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TG 435 212}} |[[AONB]], [[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 170–71 [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006073&SiteName=hickling&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Hickling Broad | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 2 June 2018}}{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006982&SiteName=martham&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Martham Broad | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 5 June 2018}} [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]],{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/hickling-broad |title= Hickling Broad|publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=21 May 2018}}{{cite web|url=https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/martham-broad |title= Martham Broad |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate= 21 May 2018}} [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1005779}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005779.pdf Citation] |This is one of the finest wetland complexes in Britain, and it is internationally important for its wetland plant communities and associated animal species. It has four lakes, [[Hickling Broad]], [[Heigham Sound]], [[Horsey Mere]] and [[Martham Broad]], together with smaller water bodies, swamp, fen, woodland and grazing marsh.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005779.pdf |title=Upper Thurne Broads and Marshes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 21 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Upton Broad and Marshes]] | [[File:A culverted drain - geograph.org.uk - 1110312.jpg|100px|alt=Upton Broad and Marshes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 195.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000299&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Upton Broad & Marshes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TG 392 137}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 172, 306–07 [[Norfolk Wildlife Trust|NWT]],{{cite web|url= https://www.norfolkwildlifetrust.org.uk/wildlife-in-norfolk/nature-reserves/reserves/upton-broad-and-marshes |title= Upton Broad and Marshes |publisher= Norfolk Wildlife Trust |accessdate=21 May 2018}} [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]], [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1000299}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000299.pdf Citation] |This is described by [[Natural England]] as "an outstanding example of unreclaimed wetland and grazing marsh". Its rich invertebrate fauna includes eighteen species of freshwater snail, and an outstanding variety of dragonflies and damselflies, including the nationally rare [[Norfolk hawker]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000299.pdf |title=Upton Broad and Marshes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 21 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|W}}[[Warham Camp]] | [[File:Warham Camp - inner wall and ditch - geograph.org.uk - 367193.jpg|100px|alt=Warham Camp ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 5.1 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000314&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Warham Camp |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Wells-next-the-Sea]]

Saltmarshes provide birds with valuable breeding grounds.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002591.pdf |title=The Wash citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 22 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wayland Wood|Wayland Wood, Watton]] | [[File:Wayland Wood, early Spring. - geograph.org.uk - 754598.jpg|100px|alt=Wayland Wood]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 31.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000350&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Wayland Wood, Watton |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Thetford]]

One arable field is reserved for uncommon [[Breckland]] plants.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002688.pdf |title=Weeting Heath citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 22 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wells Chalk Pit ]] | [[File:Wells Chalk Pit 1.jpg|100px|alt=Wells Chalk Pit ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 4.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000380&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Wells Chalk Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Wells-next-the-Sea]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TF 929 429}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2098 |title= Wells Chalk Pit (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1000380}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000380.pdf Citation] |This quarry has chalk grassland with large populations of orchids in areas which have not been worked for many years. The site is also geologically important as it exposes the glacial deposits of the Marly Drift [[till]], which was formerly believed to date to the [[Anglian glaciation]], but may belong to the more recent [[Wolstonian Stage|Wolstonian ice age]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000380.pdf |title=Wells Chalk Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 11 June 2018}}{{cite web|url=http://www.bgs.ac.uk/lexicon/lexicon.cfm?pub=LOFT|title=Lowestoft Formation|publisher=British Geological Survey|accessdate= 11 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[West Runton Cliffs]] | [[File:Cliffs at West Runton Beach - geograph.org.uk - 794779.jpg|100px|alt=West Runton Cliffs]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 17.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000393&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: West Runton Cliffs |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Cromer]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TG 187 431}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1163 |title= West Runton (Pleistocene Vertebrata) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}}{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=609 |title= West Runton (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1000393}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000393.pdf Citation] |The cliffs are important because they expose a succession of warm and cold stages in the middle [[Pleistocene]] between about 2 million and 400,000 years ago. They show a succession of advances and retreats of the sea, and the site is the [[stratotype]] for the [[Cromerian Stage]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000393.pdf |title=West Runton Cliffs citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 22 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Westwick Lakes]] | [[File:Captain's Pond - geograph.org.uk - 452138.jpg|100px|alt=Westwick Lakes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 9.8 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1000399&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Westwick Lakes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Norwich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TG 274 272}} | |{{Nature on the map|1000399}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000399.pdf Citation] |Many wildfowl over-winter on these five man-made lakes, which have unusual aquatic flora. Plants on the lake margins include [[Typha angustifolia|lesser reedmace]], [[soft rush]] and [[sweet flag]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1000399.pdf |title=Westwick Lakes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 22 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Weybourne Cliffs]] | [[File:Big chunks missing - geograph.org.uk - 747722.jpg|100px|alt=Weybourne Cliffs]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 40.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002026&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Weybourne Cliffs |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Sheringham]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TG 133 435}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=729 |title= Weybourne Cliffs (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}}{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1196 |title= Weybourne Cliffs (Pleistocene Vertebrata) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1002026}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002026.pdf Citation] |This [[Pleistocene]] site is the [[Type locality (geology)|type locality]] for the [[Pastonian Stage|Pastonian]] [[Weybourne Crag Formation]], and its fossils of marine molluscs have been studied for 200 years. Its ecological interest lies in colonies of [[sand martin]]s in the cliffs.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002026.pdf |title=Weybourne Cliffs citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 22 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Weybourne Town Pit]] | [[File:Weybourne Town Pit 1.jpg|100px|alt=Weybourne Town Pit]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 0.7 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002043&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Weybourne Town Pit |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Holt, Norfolk|Holt]]

This is a chalk-rich glacial [[till]] thought to have been deposited during the [[Anglian stage]] around 450,000 years ago, but its relationship to other deposits in the area is disputed.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002043.pdf |title=Weybourne Town Pit citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 20 November 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Whitwell Common SSSI|Whitwell Common]] | [[File:Marriott's Way footpath looking south - geograph.org.uk - 1254231.jpg|100px|alt=Whitwell Common]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 19.4 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002058&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Whitwell Common |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Norwich]]

{{gbmappingsmall|TG 086 204}} | |{{Nature on the map|1002058}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002058.pdf Citation] |This common in the valley of a tributary of the [[River Wensum]] has diverse wetland flora on peat soils. There are also areas of wet alder woodland, fen and unimproved grassland, with grasses such as [[sheep's fescue]] and [[Yorkshire fog]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002058.pdf |title= Whitwell Common citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 22 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wiggenhall St Germans SSSI|Wiggenhall St Germans]] | [[File:Wiggenhall St Germans SSSI 1.jpg|100px|alt=Wiggenhall St Germans]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 5.2 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1005805&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Wiggenhall St. Germans |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord|52.699|0.349 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wiggenhall St. Germans}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TF 588 138}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2528 |title= Wiggenhall St Germans (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1005805}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005805.pdf Citation] |This site provides evidence for sea level changes during the [[Quaternary]] period, the last 2.6 million years. There are three peat layers, interspersed with fine-grained [[clastic rock]]s, and they have been studied with pollen and [[ foraminifera]] analyses.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1005805.pdf |title=Wiggenhall St Germans citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 4 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Winterton-Horsey Dunes]] | [[File:Pillbox near Horsey Gap - geograph.org.uk - 1705598.jpg|100px|alt=Winterton-Horsey Dunes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 427.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1004453&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Winterton-Horsey Dunes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|YES | [[Great Yarmouth]]
{{coord|52.733|1.678 |type:landmark_region:GB|name= Winterton-Horsey Dunes}}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 484 214}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2104 |title= Winterton Ness (Coastal Geomorphology of England) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} [[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 9–10 [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=1006159&SiteName=winterton&countyCode=&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Winterton Dunes | series= National Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 2 June 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]],{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteGeneralDetail.aspx?SiteCode=UK0013043&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&unitId=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Winterton-Horsey Dunes | series=Special Areas of Conservation|publisher=Natural England|accessdate = 2 June 2018}} [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1004453}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004453.pdf Citation] |This site has extensive dunes together with areas of grazing marsh and birch woodland. Invertebrates include a rare amphibian and a rare butterfly. The site is geologically important as it displays the processes which control dynamic dune development.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1004453.pdf |title=Winterton-Horsey Dunes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 23 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wiveton Downs]] | [[File:Wiveton Downs - geograph.org.uk - 113424.jpg|100px|alt=Wiveton Downs ]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 28.9 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002122&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Wiveton Downs |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate=17 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Holt, Norfolk|Holt]]
{{coord| 52.944|1.012|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Wiveton Downs }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 025 428}} |[[AONB]], [[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]],{{cite web|url=http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=603 |title= Wiveton Downs (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}}{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=2347 |title= Blakeney Esker (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 23 June 2018}} [[Local Nature Reserve|LNR]]{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteLNRDetail.aspx?SiteCode=L1009249&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea=|title= Designated Sites View: Wiveton Down |series=Local Nature Reserves|publisher=Natural England |accessdate= 21 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1002122}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002122.pdf Citation] |This is a classic example of an [[esker]], a glacial crevasse which has been filled in until it forms a narrow winding ridge. It has been very important for teaching, research and demonstration.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002122.pdf |title= Wiveton Downs citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 23 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wretham Park Meres]] | [[File:West Mere 3.jpg|100px|alt=Wretham Park Meres]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 30.0 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url=https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1002144&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= |title=Designated Sites View: Wretham Park Meres |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|NO | [[Thetford]]
{{coord|52.491|0.807 |type:landmark_region:GB|name=Wretham Park Meres }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TL 907 918}} | |{{Nature on the map|1002144}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002144.pdf Citation] |This site consists of four natural lakes, Mickle Mere, Hill Mere, Rush Mere and West Mere, which provide a breeding habitat for wildfowl such as [[mallard]]s, [[gadwall]]s, [[Northern shoveler|shovelers]], [[tufted duck]]s and [[Eurasian teal|teal]]. There are also many wintering ducks.{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1002144.pdf |title=Wretham Park Meres citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 30 September 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|[[Wretton SSSI|Wretton]] | [[File:Cut Off Channel - geograph.org.uk - 570152.jpg|100px|alt=Wretton]] | align="center"| | align="center"|{{y}} | {{convert| 20.6 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1003441&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Wretton |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[King's Lynn]]
{{coord| 52.565|0.483|type:landmark_region:GB|name= Wretton}}
{{gbmappingsmall| TL 684 992}} |[[Geological Conservation Review|GCR]]{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=1164|title= Wretton (Pleistocene Vertebrata)|series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}}{{cite web|url= http://jncc.defra.gov.uk/default.aspx?page=4174&gcr=604 |title= Wretton (Quaternary of East Anglia) |series=Geological Conservation Review |publisher=Joint Nature Conservation Committee|accessdate= 25 May 2018}} |{{Nature on the map|1003441}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003441.pdf Citation] |This site exposes layer across the transition between the warm [[Ipswichian]] and the colder [[Devensian]] around 115,000 years ago. It has the richest assemblage of early Devensian vertebrate fossils in Britain, including [[arctic fox]], [[bison]] and [[woolly rhinoceros]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1003441.pdf |title=Wretton citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 24 June 2018}} |- ! scope="row"|{{anchor|Y}}[[Yare Broads and Marshes]] | [[File:Church Marsh Nature Reserve in early May - geograph.org.uk - 1285298.jpg|100px|alt=Yare Broads and Marshes]] | align="center"|{{y}} | align="center"| | {{convert| 744.5 |ha|acre |sortable=on|disp=br()}}{{Cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/SiteDetail.aspx?SiteCode=S1001231&SiteName=&countyCode=29&responsiblePerson=&SeaArea=&IFCAArea= | title=Designated Sites View: Yare Broads and Marshes |series=Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 17 May 2018}} | align="center"|PP | [[Norwich]]
{{coord| 52.602|1.448|type:landmark_region:GB|name=Yare Broads and Marshes }}
{{gbmappingsmall|TG 336 061}} |[[Nature Conservation Review|NCR]],Ratcliffe, pp. 209–10 [[National nature reserve (United Kingdom)|NNR]], [[Ramsar site|Ramsar]], [[RSPB]],{{cite web|url= https://www.rspb.org.uk/reserves-and-events/reserves-a-z/strumpshaw-fen/ |title= Strumpshaw Fen|publisher=Royal Society for the Protection of Birds| accessdate= 2 June 2018}}{{cite web|url= https://www.rspb.org.uk/reserves-and-events/reserves-a-z/surlingham-church-marsh |title= Surlingham Church Marsh|publisher=Royal Society for the Protection of Birds|accessdate= 24 June 2018}} [[Special Area of Conservation|SAC]], [[Special Protection Area|SPA]] |{{Nature on the map|1001231}} |[https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001231.pdf Citation] |This is a nationally important wetland site, with grazing marsh, open water, fen, carr woodland and peat. There are many nationally rare plants and many birds including nationally important wintering flocks of [[wigeon]].{{cite web|url= https://designatedsites.naturalengland.org.uk/PDFsForWeb/Citation/1001231.pdf |title=Yare Broads and Marshes citation|series= Sites of Special Scientific Interest|publisher=Natural England|accessdate= 24 June 2018}} |} ==See also== {{commons category|Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Norfolk}} *[[National Nature Reserves in Norfolk]] *[[List of Local Nature Reserves in Norfolk]] *[[Norfolk Wildlife Trust]] ==Notes== {{Notelist}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{coord|52|40|N|1|00|E|region:GB_type:adm1st|display=title}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|editor-first=Derek |editor-last=Ratcliffe |title=A Nature Conservation Review |volume=2 |authorlink=Derek Ratcliffe |publisher=Cambridge University Press |location=Cambridge, UK |year=1977 |isbn=0-521-21403-3}} {{SSSIs Norfolk}} {{SSSI AOS lists}} [[Category:Sites of Special Scientific Interest in Norfolk| ]] [[Category:Lists of Sites of Special Scientific Interest by Area of Search|Norfolk]] [[Category:Norfolk-related lists|Sites of Special Scientific Interest]]

{{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''Streptomyces'' species}} There are roughly 550 '''species of ''[[Streptomyces]]''''' bacteria recognized at present, but new ones are still being discovered (e.g., ''[[Streptomyces boninensis|S. boninensis]]'' and ''[[Streptomyces fuscigenes|S. fuscigenes]]'', both described in 2018).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Lee|first1=HJ|last2=Whang|first2=KS|title=Streptomyces fuscigenes sp. nov., isolated from bamboo (Sasa borealis) litter.|journal=International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology|date=14 March 2018|doi=10.1099/ijsem.0.002706|pmid=29537363}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last1=Také|first1=A|last2=Inahashi|first2=Y|last3=Ōmura|first3=S|last4=Takahashi|first4=Y|last5=Matsumoto|first5=A|title=Streptomyces boninensis sp. nov., isolated from soil from a limestone cave in the Ogasawara Islands.|journal=International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology|date=6 April 2018|doi=10.1099/ijsem.0.002753|pmid=29624162}}</ref> Many species are named after their colorful [[hyphae]] and/or [[spore]]s.
